- Data collection participants: The Professor asked to begin recruiting about 50 subjects immediately (starting with CogSci classes but not limited to students), using the already-approved consent form. The Professor’s change request was operational: port and debug their code (especially neural-net training and HTK workflows) on this Linux system now, enable multithreading/parallel training, and sort out scripts so they’re ready when IBM supplies the remaining processors. They also suggested checking Linux on existing machines (e.g., Swede, Fudge) for quicker wins.

In short: switch the system to idiomatic English (parser/templates/ontology summaries), recruit subjects using the consent form plus a new transcript-waiver option, and prepare/parallelize code on the IBM Linux hardware.

The group framed decisions like Go-there and Endpoint (enter/view/approach) as belief-net nodes fed by four “experts”: user (U), situation (S), discourse (D), and ontology/entity (E). They saw strong value in separating user and situation models so each can contribute compact, reusable evidence rather than dumping every feature directly into a single CPT. To keep models tractable, they proposed intermediate variables—especially a “compatibility with action” node that aggregates user state (money, time, energy/fatigue, schedule) and aligns it with action requirements; this can be reused across decisions.

User model:
- Distinguishes a running User budget (a numeric, externally updated resource) from a User finance trait (cheap/average/spendy). Budget updates occur outside the BN and may trigger belief propagation either immediately or on demand.
- Because decisions are discrete, the numeric budget should be mapped to decision-specific ranges/thresholds (e.g., admission fees). Thriftiness and admission costs together reduce the probability of “enter.”
- A large interests vector (≈500 topics) motivates an externally computed “fit” node to express how well an entity matches the user’s interests.

Situation model:
- Encodes temporally varying facts (open/closed, strikes, accessibility, whether the user has a base in town). These affect Go-there and Endpoint differently; for example, closed matters if “enter” is intended but not if “view.”
- They noted the need to avoid loops; Endpoint can inform Go-there via an intermediate node.

For combining U/S/D/E, they favored weighted voting over full CPT specification, and discussed a mixture-of-experts (hidden selector) to vary weights by context. Overall, user and situation models are essential for realistic, context-sensitive decisions, provided they are abstracted into compact, reusable nodes to avoid combinatorial blow-up.

The industrial manager (industrial designer) highlighted the tiger’s behavioral traits as the key qualities worth studying for the remote-control design. Specifically, he emphasized:

- Methodical, well-thought action: The tiger “hunts for prey” in a deliberate, carefully planned way. This underscores precision, intentionality, and an avoidance of unnecessary complexity—valuing designs that do exactly what’s needed with clarity and purpose.

- Security-first mindset: He noted the tiger “always goes for security,” seeking a safe, advantageous position before acting. This points to reliability, risk reduction, and user confidence—features that make interactions feel safe, predictable, and under control.

- Stealth and concealment: By “seeking a hide spot,” the tiger uses concealment and positioning. Translated to product qualities, this suggests unobtrusive form, clean integration into environments, and controls that are accessible without being intrusive or confusing.

- Focus and efficiency: Implicit in a planned hunt is conserving effort and maximizing impact—favoring streamlined, efficient interactions over flashy but distracting elements.

In short, the characteristics singled out were the tiger’s strategic, carefully planned behavior; its constant prioritization of security; and its use of stealth and advantageous positioning. These traits were proposed as guiding principles for a design that is purposeful, reliable, unobtrusive, and efficient—prioritizing user certainty and effective, straightforward operation over showiness or unnecessary complexity.

- Current interface (Transcriber + hacks): The team said the interface prevents detailed overlap annotation—transcribers can’t mark precise start/end times for each overlap. It displays only one waveform, and the Tcl/Tk graphics make loading and switching visual waveforms painfully slow. Switching audio between channels currently requires menu navigation, which is inefficient. Despite this, transcribers mainly rely on listening; visuals are secondary. Proposed near-term fixes: show only the mixed waveform with a UI to edit channel ribbons, add a fast “click-to-switch-audio” control, and generate separate output files per channel to preserve overlaps and enable clean single-channel exports. Dan Ellis’s hack allows choosing which channel to listen to (but still only one displayed waveform). Dave Gelbart volunteered to modify Transcriber accordingly.

- Ideal/longer-term direction: Broad agreement that a “musical score” style interface (multiple channels on a single timeline with precise overlap marking) would be best. Gelbart has concrete ideas to extend the interface toward this.

- Alternative tools explored: An LMU Munich tool exists but is proprietary, unsupported, and considered error‑prone, so not usable. Susanne Burger (CMU) has an 8‑channel transcription tool the team would like to try; if it works, they’ll arrange Windows machines. Praat (PRAAT) was considered but judged likely unsuitable for their specific needs.

- Practical decision and timing: To keep data flowing, they will proceed with the existing setup using a coarse timescale for overlaps, while trying to land the improved overlap encoding “this week” if possible. They noted they may not need a large, long‑term transcription operation if external transcripts arrive, but still want better tools for accurate overlap coding and channel‑separable outputs.

Components design and remote components: Internals are standard—PCB with IR LED, IC, battery, and switches. Company can supply off‑the‑shelf speakers/beepers for feedback and a “find‑me” bleep. Button options included push‑buttons (company expertise), a scroll/spinning wheel (with integrated push), and an LCD (requires advanced IC). Power options discussed: standard AA battery (preferred for reliability/cost), kinetic backup (attractive but uncertain practicality), solar (conflicts with latex/rubber skins), and a docking/charging base as a differentiator.

Properties and materials: Strong preference for a solid plastic body with soft rubber over‑mould/grips for drop resistance and hand feel; wood rejected; titanium considered “chic” but less aligned with sturdy, playful positioning and double‑curvature constraints. Case shape should be single/double‑curved, “fruity” and ergonomic; two‑tone colourways (case vs rubber pads/buttons).

Conceptual specifications of user interface and interface contents: Keep essentials as large physical controls: power, channel up/down, volume up/down; numbers and/or favourites/presets debated. Advanced functions via a simple menu: either on‑TV OSD navigated with arrows, or a small flip‑open LCD with a wheel (contentious on cost/fragility and design coherence). Secondary ideas: last‑channel toggle, parental control profiles/login, voice recognition (optional/secondary), spoken feedback.

Market findings and trend watching/market trends: Research ranked “fancy look & feel” first, technology second, ease of use third (some scepticism noted). Younger users favour soft, colourful, “spongy” materials; seniors prefer darker, traditional looks—solution: removable/colour covers and dark variants. Year’s themes: fruits/vegetables and tactile/spongy textures; use rounded “fruity” forms and catchy but not overbearing colours, while retaining brand colours. Overall, the direction balances fashion-forward appearance with simplicity, robustness, and tight cost (≈€25) constraints.

Members heard that the early implementer areas are broadly successful and valuable precisely because they are pilots. Key lessons:

- Administration: The biggest issue is the bureaucratic burden on councils and parents (eligibility checks, wage slips, birth certificates, changes in work patterns). This argues strongly for a single, centralised HMRC-style eligibility system with data sharing (e.g., DWP) to simplify access and reduce local workload; this is the Government’s preferred approach under the Childcare Funding (Wales) Bill.

- Demand and geography: Demand is uneven across and within pilot areas for economic and cultural reasons (e.g., strong traditions of informal family childcare in some Valleys communities). Pilots also exposed “boundary” frustrations where only parts of an authority are included.

- Capacity and workforce: No systemic capacity problems have emerged (including Welsh-medium and complex needs), but some areas face workforce shortages rather than space constraints. Pilots are helping map gaps, supported by a £60m capital programme, a 10‑year workforce plan, co‑location with schools, and targeted Welsh‑medium expansion via Mudiad Meithrin.

- Pricing and affordability: The £4.50 hourly rate is widely welcomed and deliberately simpler than England’s model, but high‑cost urban areas (Cardiff/Newport) will test whether a universal rate is viable; differential rates remain a possibility if evidence demands it. Providers may charge for food/transport/consumables, which will be monitored to avoid disadvantaging low‑income families.

- Roll‑out approach: A phased expansion (e.g., Gwynedd, Anglesey, Caerphilly, Flintshire; RCT and Swansea next) is preferred to England’s “big‑bang,” reducing technical and volume risks and allowing continuous learning.

Overall, the pilots are refining eligibility processes, communications with parents and providers, capacity planning (including Welsh‑medium growth), and the funding model ahead of full roll‑out by 2020.

- Speech/voice recognition: The PM was skeptical from the start. After reviewing an in‑house “speaker/microphone” module that only matched fixed phrases, he called it a fancy but pointless gimmick for interaction. He flagged major issues (training for many phrases, TV/background noise, multi‑language support, complexity) and repeatedly ruled ASR out for the prototype. When asked to add simple keyword spotting (“volume up”), he said it was too difficult for this cycle; if anything, it might be revisited in later versions.

- Cost constraints: He enforced a strict target (≈€25 retail, ≈€12.5 production). Anything above made the project a no‑go. To stay within budget, he cut speech recognition and special colors, pushed customizable covers as paid extras, and favored in‑house, low‑risk components.

- LCD incorporation: Initially hesitant due to space/cost, he later chose to keep the LCD and drop ASR. He saw the LCD as more valuable than speech recognition—useful for menus/advanced settings (e.g., brightness, favorites) and potentially channel navigation—though he admitted it wasn’t yet perfectly leveraged.

- Button design: He advocated minimal, easy controls: two scroll wheels (channel and volume) positioned for the thumb, a “turbo” option for rapid zapping, and just a few essential buttons (power, menu, OK). He supported avoiding number clutter, rounded ergonomics, and a “spongy” rubberized feel for durability and distinctiveness.

- Overall technology stance: Pragmatic and user‑value driven—favoring scroll wheels, a locator/beeper (with a base station), and TV‑only scope, while avoiding costly, immature, or internet‑dependent features that jeopardize budget or usability.

- Recording conventions: The group agreed to standardize on close-talking, head‑mounted microphones rather than lapels, to reduce variability across speakers, improve recognition and prosody work, and make transcription easier. Placement guidance was specified (boom near the corner of the mouth, about a thumb to thumb‑and‑a‑half away, to avoid breath noise). They plan to buy several identical, more comfortable headsets and prefer uniformity over variety; broken channels will be fixed, and both wired and wireless are acceptable, with wireless expansion (additional base station, daisy‑chaining) under consideration. MultiTrans is being modified to support multi‑channel recordings with tighter time marks on overlaps; pre‑segmentation and channel‑energy cues will guide transcribers. Transcription conventions are being tightened (systematic handling of numbers and acronyms; tags like VOC, NONVOC, GLOSS), with an emphasis on reliability and compatibility with ATLAS.

- On incorporating video: Interest was acknowledged, but the team decided not to add video now. Reasons included infrastructure and setup burden, increased human‑subjects/privacy concerns, likely participant reluctance, lack of an internal champion, storage/synchronization complexity (mirrored in similar concerns about microphone arrays), and a focus on impromptu scenarios that won’t realistically have instrumented rooms. The consensus was that organizations like NIST/LDC are better positioned to manage video meeting corpora. They are open to collaborators who want to deploy video or arrays as a separate, unsynchronized setup in the same room and then export that data, but the core project will continue with audio‑only, standardized headsets and improved multi‑channel/time‑alignment tools.

Project finance was framed by a target retail price of €25 and an overall profit goal of €50M. Early on, the team flagged likely cost issues and, lacking detailed cost data at the start, they later had to prune features to fit the financial criteria. During the finance review they walked through a component-cost sheet, debating how items (e.g., pushbuttons) were counted. To hit budget, they removed the pricey “sample speaker/sensor” (calling it a gimmick) and replaced it with a simple beeper while keeping a locator function. They also dropped the scroll wheel in favor of volume up/down buttons to save cost, retained the LCD and voice recognition, and left headroom for potential color/finish upcharges. They joked about low-cost manufacturing but the substantive outcome was a configuration “well within budget,” with even a small buffer for unforeseen items. In retrospectives, they noted the late arrival of cost information constrained creativity and recommended providing the cost sheet at project start; marketing was tasked to validate whether €25 matches market expectations.

Use of the drawing board (whiteboard/Smart Board) was integral. The team trained on it early and used it continually to sketch form, UI layouts, a second-level sliding panel, teletext states, and button placement, saving the drawings as artifacts. They found it superior to static slides for rapid iteration, brainstorming, and capturing evolving decisions, and praised having both whiteboard and PowerPoint in the room.   - Focused on form and usability: a single curved body, good hand feel, color-separated key groups, and a slide-away second layer for less-used functions. He pushed ergonomic improvements and warned that replacing discrete keys with an integrated scroll-wheel would hurt ease-of-use.
  - Sought a balanced “fashion vs. innovation” mix via special-form/fruit-themed buttons, while being willing to trade rubber casing for plastic to hit cost targets. He also suggested a simple locator concept to find a lost remote.

- Project Manager’s thinking during discussions:
  - Set and reinforced constraints: €25 retail and production ≤ €12.5, plus visible brand identity. Kept scope to a basic TV remote and pushed simplicity (infrared, battery power) unless strong justification.
  - Continuously reconciled features with the cost model, highlighting trade-offs (e.g., if speech stays, downgrade materials/colors; plastic casing saves ~2 units vs. rubber). Drove structured evaluation against criteria and insisted decisions reflect marketing data.

- PM’s conclusions from team presentations:
  - Proceed with a basic, ergonomic TV remote aligned to Real Reaction’s look; prefer infrared and (initially) batteries; consider a lock/flip and a finder function.
  - To meet cost: use a plastic case, limit special colors/materials, and keep only the most value-adding innovation (LCD and/or kinetic power), not the full set. The prototype largely met goals but needed cost-down adjustments and usability refinements to balance “fancy” appeal with clarity.

- Decision on the base: The team weighed a small, battery-powered remote versus a larger unit with a charging base. They concluded that a dock would feel clunky and irritate users if the remote were compact, so they chose a smaller, stand‑free design with a locator feature to mitigate loss. For power they rejected solar (incompatible with soft covers) and kinetic/dynamo (user effort), and selected a single lithium cell for light weight. Separately, when “base” meant the product’s base finish, they chose a gun‑metal gray plastic body (with optional bright-yellow branding accents).

In the quick 7‑point rating of the clay prototype, fashion scored low (it was only a rough model), but they aligned on a look that blends sleek, simple, iPod‑like cues with trend-aware options. They rejected heavy fruit/vegetable patterns as too faddish, opting instead for an ergonomic, organic form, limited tasteful color accents, full-body illumination on press, and interchangeable latex covers so trends (e.g., cherries) can be offered without locking the core product into a gimmick.

- Pros and cons of existing remotes: They disliked LCD remotes as costly, potentially confusing, and unnecessary (users don’t look at the remote while watching TV). Oversized models were deemed gimmicky, though tactile/raised symbols were a plus. Side scrolls are familiar but risk accidental activation; the team proposed side-mounted up/down controls that must be depressed to engage and be clearly labeled. Child covers that fall off were noted as a flaw; voice control for commands was seen as complex, but a voice/whistle-style finder was acceptable.

- Environment-friendly material: The team proposed using shape-memory alloys for fast end-of-life disassembly (heat to release fasteners), enabling reuse/recycling via a take-back program. They weighed costs against a 100% turnover target. For power, solar was deemed impractical indoors; kinetic/dynamo ideas were intriguing but potentially inconvenient; batteries remain likely, with energy-saving features.

- Current trend: Market and fashion-watch inputs said “fancy look and feel” will dominate over pure functionality, with a fruit-and-vegetable theme and spongy/tactile finishes trending. Some worried about short-lived fads and advised balancing trendiness with longevity and broad appeal.

- Potential materials: Options included hard plastic, rubber/latex over a rigid shell, wood, and titanium. A titanium back/plastic front was discussed, but double curvature and weight/cost concerns (and one warning that titanium suits flat cases) made plastic with metallic finishes more feasible.

- LCD screen: Pros—supports menus, reduces button clutter, trendy. Cons—needs an advanced chip, adds cost/power, small/readability issues. Alternative was on-TV menus controlled by few buttons/scroll; teletext was dropped as outdated/internationally inconsistent. Speech recognition was rejected for cost/noise/limited utility.

- Color: Bright/primary “fruity” colors, mismatched accents accepted, and interchangeable fronts/covers (iPod/phone style). Company logo present; silver/yellow considered for base.

- Spongy material: Favor a thin latex/rubber overmold (stress-ball-like grip) on a hard inner case; possibility of swappable squishy sleeves themed by fruits/vegetables, avoiding childish looks.

- Material/function trade-offs: Strong look vs soft touch; curved ergonomics; minimize buttons for ease while keeping durability (embossed/tactile, timed backlighting vs glow-in-the-dark).

- Questionnaire: 7‑point scale on features, innovation (LCD vs speech), fancy look, ease. Results suggested moderate success on “fashion in electronics,” constrained by budget; prior research showed users pay more for aesthetic appeal, while high voice-recognition interest wasn’t pursued.

Introduction of the prototype(s):
- The Project Manager opened by fixing a strict unit cost target (12.50€) and framing evaluation. Two concepts were shown. The User Interface lead introduced a basic, TV‑only remote (~8€) with a conventional keypad and a second “smooth” concept (~16€) with only six multifunction keys, an LCD that indicates mode, a device-toggle, a power key, channel/volume controls, a microphone for speech recognition, and a small LED for battery/locator feedback, plus a protective cover. The Industrial Designer emphasized distinctive forms to convey “surfing” (surfboard shape) and later presented a banana-shaped, rubberized, “spongy” model with iPod‑like scroll navigation, ergonomic grip, and bright color for visibility.

Multi‑functional vs single‑functional:
- The group converged on a single‑function, TV‑only remote. Reasons: simplicity and ease of use; lower learning burden; better cross‑brand compatibility; and, crucially, cost/complexity—multi‑device control (TV/DVD/VCR) and teletext would push them over budget. Management also mandated dropping teletext and focusing on TV-only. A device-toggle idea was discussed early but abandoned.

Lower technological grades:
- The basic remote scored low on innovation because it mirrored existing market products (“no innovation”). The more advanced features (LCD, speech recognition) were attractive but unaffordable within 12.50€. After cutting LCD and speech recognition to meet cost, the banana prototype earned only moderate tech marks (e.g., ~4) since remaining novelties (scroll wheel, lighting) were incremental, not breakthrough.

Locator consideration:
- “Findability” was treated as a requirement. Options explored included: a blinking LED that doubles as low‑battery/locator cue; a clap‑to‑beep or alarm; a two‑piece beeper (adhesive tag on the TV plus a responder in the remote); a TV “beeper” button; and visual aids (bright yellow case, glow‑in‑the‑dark or timed backlit buttons). Voice‑calling the remote via speech recognition was noted but deemed costly and noise‑sensitive. The team leaned toward low‑cost beeper/LED and high‑visibility materials.

- Agreement between PhD A and PhD C on variance: They converged on using variance-based characterizations from the “excitation” (FFT minus smoothed mel-filter spectrum) to help separate voiced vs. unvoiced frames. PhD A showed that the feature’s means differ (≈0.30 unvoiced vs. ≈0.59 voiced) but with substantial overlap; it appears robust to noise. PhD C agreed it is promising but cautioned that the ground-truth (TIMIT canonical phone mappings) could inflate variance and blur separability. Both agreed not to rely on simple mean/variance thresholds or log-domain normalization; instead, examine full distributions (histograms), try alternative statistical characterizations of the difference between raw and smoothed spectra, and evaluate them in a trained model (e.g., NN or as added features in the recognizer) rather than assuming Gaussianity.

- Discussion with Jose: Jose reported large variation across overlap types; energy is not consistently higher during overlap, and log-energy compresses differences. He and the group agreed to: (1) start with simple, unnormalized linear-energy histograms for single vs. overlap, (2) systematically vary window sizes and normalization domains (avoid subtract/divide in the log domain by default), (3) explore CDF/PDF approaches without normality assumptions, and (4) prioritize pitch/harmonicity features as likely stronger indicators. They also discussed labeling specific overlap classes (e.g., short backchannels) and possibly analyzing clean two-speaker subsets.

- Problems/difficulties due to overlaps: Overlap phenomena are heterogeneous (backchannels vs. competitive talk), causing heavy distributional overlap and weak separability by energy alone. Log compression, crude gain normalization, and ill-chosen window lengths obscure cues. Short backchannels are easily washed out by long normalization windows. Reliable analysis depends on accurate time marks/forced alignment; current segmentation sometimes splits words or mixes channels. Equipment/breath noise and speaker loudness differences further confound features. Overall, success likely requires better features (pitch/harmonicity), tailored normalization, and curated overlap labels.

The team flagged new latency introduced by the denoising front end, specifically the smoothed spectral-subtraction stage. To stabilize the time-varying gain and reduce musical noise, the method uses a centered recursion that looks ahead into future frames. That future look-ahead creates added delay; the presenter confirmed a look-ahead of about “five-zero,” i.e., roughly 50 ms. Related pieces also impose delay: initial noise estimation that uses the first 10–20 frames of an utterance (≈100–200 ms), and transport/scheduling that bundles audio into super-frames (e.g., 24 frames), making the first frame in a bundle incur ≈24-frame latency (~240 ms) while the last has essentially none.

The professor’s issue was not with the idea of smoothing per se, but with the cumulative impact of latency on an interactive system (SmartKom). He warned that if they ignore latency now, they may be forced later to “cut the latency in half,” creating a late-stage crunch. He urged being conservative: minimize added look-ahead where possible (e.g., prefer past-only processing even if it costs ~3% relative accuracy), and consider system-level strategies (buffering so latencies are not additive, or two-pass recognition: fast first pass with short context, then a very fast second pass using longer-context features on a small N-best/lattice).

Durations mentioned:
- Smoothing look-ahead: ~50 ms (centered recursion).
- Noise-estimate warm-up: 10–20 frames (~100–200 ms).
- Super-frame buffering: up to 24 frames for the earliest frame (~240 ms, variable within the bundle).
Overall, the concern is keeping end-to-end interaction responsive while balancing accuracy gains from longer temporal context.

- Ergonomic, hand-friendly form factor: The case was specified with an ergonomic shape to sit comfortably in the hand. The device was intentionally given some heft so it doesn’t feel flimsy, improving perceived control and quality.

- Customizable wooden enclosure: Wood was chosen for the case, with color achieved via stain. Advantage: a warm, premium feel and easy aesthetic personalization without tooling changes.

- Flip-panel with integrated LCD (yellow display): An LCD screen is placed under a flip cover. Advantage: provides visual feedback and richer controls when needed, yet remains hidden for simplicity; it is also modular—if cost proves too high, it can be omitted without redesigning the whole remote.

- Clear, accessible control layout: A large, highly visible yellow on/off button makes power easy to find. A dark‑blue numeric keypad sits at the bottom for quick entry. Menu controls are grouped on the right; a dedicated control on the left toggles voice recognition. Advantage: spatial grouping accelerates learning and supports quick, eyes-off operation; the voice toggle gives users privacy and avoids accidental activation.

- Built-in voice recognition with always-available mic: The microphone should be placed on the top/side (not under the flip) so voice can be used even when the remote is closed or not in hand. Advantage: true hands‑free use (e.g., when hands are occupied), aligning with the key differentiator.

- Personalizable surfaces: Custom back plates (and potentially the flip front) allow user or brand customization, subject to PCB clearance. Advantage: differentiation and user affinity.

- Tactile button design: “Egg-shaped” buttons considered for better feel and identification by touch (with a note on cost trade‑offs). Advantage: enhances usability without relying solely on sight.

Presentation: The team showed a modular remote-control prototype offered in two versions: (1) with an LCD and (2) without. Both versions shared a minimalist hardware layout built around a single 360-degree “joystick” button (with click/double-click) for navigation/selection, a side microphone for optional speech-recognition, and a small on/off switch for that feature. Power came from a single rechargeable AA cell; charging was via a simple dock/phone-style charger. A beeper/“misplacement reminder” and message prompt encouraged returning the unit to the charger. The industrial design emphasized robustness (a silver/titanium-like shell) with discussion of later spongy/soft-touch skins; add-on modules were proposed for parental controls and an elderly-friendly big-button face.

Discussion: Costs for the fully loaded configuration were estimated at about $15 (above the ~€12.5 target), with rough breakdowns: base unit ~$4, LCD ~$2, speech/mic ~$2, parental/other modules ~$2, charger ~$3. Marketing stressed that buyers value fancy, colorful, spongy looks more than tech add-ons, and that removing the LCD would free shape/finish options and reduce cost. The team debated detachable modules (flexible, upgradable, keeps customers returning) versus integrating everything (avoids lost parts); the PM favored integration for reliability, while others liked modularity. Fanciness was self-rated around 3 (with LCD) and 4 (without); innovativeness was judged high in both; ease-of-use scored 6 due to the few-button approach.

Conclusion: Proceed with the simpler, LCD-free version to hit cost and improve form freedom; keep speech recognition as an optional/deferred module. Maintain the core appearance as a robust, titanium-looking body with potential spongy/fruit-themed skins later, and refine the second (alternative button) layout. Focus next on aesthetics, cost optimization, and finalizing the dock/locator.

- Touch screen: Initially floated as a marquee feature (and later revisited), but an internal cost estimate put it at about €17.50 per unit versus a target build cost under ~€12.50. It also raised power demands. The team concluded to drop the touch screen for the first model, positioning voice recognition (which they already have in-house) as the premium feature instead. They left open the option to revisit touch screens in a later version.

- Flip screen / flip top: Early UI concepts proposed a flip-up panel to prevent accidental presses, optionally host a small LCD, and lock controls when closed—useful around kids. They noted weight implications (especially with earlier wood-case ideas). In later discussions, with the touchscreen removed, they kept the flip/slide-out idea as a low-cost way to hide advanced functions while keeping the top surface simple.

- Batteries and power: They debated AAA (bulky) vs coin cells, and considered a rechargeable pack with a cradle (phone-style) to avoid frequent replacements. For low-cost “find me” functionality they preferred a TV-mounted beep trigger over pricier options. A battery-life indicator LED was proposed. Later they explored solar plus a small backup cell (basement scenarios noted), and briefly kinetic harvesting (likely insufficient for a touch display). Lithium availability was constrained by the current manufacturer.

- General functionality under budget: Keep it TV-only, simple primary controls (power, channel, volume), rubber buttons for durability, and minimal on-device complexity; advanced functions live under the flip/slide panel. A small LCD was treated as optional and subject to cost-benefit (the TV itself is the main display). Voice recognition remains the distinctive, marketable feature within budget.

The Government says it has embedded the key lessons from the three‑year Schools Challenge Cymru (SCC) into its wider school‑improvement system. Core takeaways include: the primacy of strong, capable leadership; robust systems for individual pupil tracking and data‑driven processes; a consistent focus on pedagogy and teaching quality; and collaborative, school‑to‑school working within a self‑improving system. It has also invested in lasting capacity, transferring many of SCC’s strongest advisers into the regional consortia and strengthening regional improvement functions.

Progression is now delivered through the national categorisation model rather than a standalone SCC programme. Improvement boards established under SCC have been retained. Support is targeted by need across all schools (including primaries), not just the original 39 secondaries. “Red” schools are entitled to up to 25 days of regional support—more than the c.20 days SCC provided—allowing intensive intervention where warranted. Government cites sustained improvements in some former SCC schools (e.g., Tredegar moving to “green” status and Eastern High coming out of special measures), while acknowledging that SCC had less impact in some settings; those schools are now being supported through the strengthened regional model.

Although SCC was always time‑limited, Ministers emphasise its legacy: over £10 million invested in regional school‑improvement capacity, continuity of effective personnel, and the mainstreaming of SCC practices into the national mission. Some early tensions between SCC activity and consortia roles were reported but are said to have been resolved as the system transitioned. The current focus is a whole‑system approach—using categorisation, leadership development, rigorous tracking, and collaboration—to sustain gains where SCC worked well and to intensify support where it did not.

Dr. David Blaney views Brexit chiefly as a source of significant uncertainty that risks the higher education system’s capacity to deliver for Wales. He notes early, tangible effects: a fall in EU-domiciled applications to Welsh universities and anecdotal signs that Welsh/UK institutions are finding it harder to join EU-funded research consortia as partners question UK stability during the transition. Given universities’ exposure to EU-derived income (students, research, structural funds), he anticipates turbulence, with the eventual scale depending on UK–EU outcomes and UK–Welsh Government funding decisions.

On the 8–9% drop in EU applications to Wales (contrasting with growth in England), Blaney points to two main factors. First, the change to student support for EU students in Wales—moving from receiving a grant to needing a full-fee loan—has likely caused a short-term perturbation; he hopes this is temporary and stresses the Welsh offer is at least as good as England’s and slightly better on fee levels. Second, in a highly competitive market, visible investment matters: long-standing lower capital investment in parts of the Welsh estate may make some campuses appear less attractive. He also cites Wales’s smaller share of high-tariff, globally prominent institutions and the Anglocentric UK media limiting Wales’s visibility; perceptions of welcome can influence international demand.

As to why study in Wales, Blaney highlights: a UK-quality degree in a setting perceived by international students and parents as safer and more supportive, with smaller, more manageable cities; slightly lower fees than England; and a strengthened, sector-led “Study in Wales” offer that markets these advantages internationally.

Mental-space domains. The group treats mental spaces as small “worlds” built by space builders in the utterance and context. Core domains:
- Time: deictic “now,” “past,” “future” (past as a conventional space builder relative to speech time).
- Space: deictic “here/there,” locations like “in France,” with relations to the event’s place.
- Person/indexicals: speaker, hearer, logophoric shifts (e.g., reported speech, ASL role shift).
- Modality/attitude: belief, desire, counterfactual/conditional (“if,” “would”), factivity/evidentiality.
- Discourse context/accessibility: active/accessible referents; retrieval from context is handled with the same accessibility/mapping machinery as other spaces.
Each utterance selects a base space and may open embedded spaces; pronouns, tense, and reference are interpreted relative to the current base. Spaces are connected by mappings/identifications (sometimes partial), allowing blends when needed.

Middle layer function. In the tourist domain Bayes net, the middle layer consists of hidden conceptual variables that mediate between observed features and the output “mode” (Enter/Tango/Vista). It captures plans/roles such as:
- Tourist vs doing-business/errand
- In-a-hurry vs leisurely
- Has-final-destination vs meandering
- Intends-to-enter (optional), etc.
Inputs come from multiple observable regions: discourse cues (e.g., admission-fee talk), parse/lexicon (verb class), prosody (tense/relaxed), context (time of day), and ontology (enterable/has-door, landmark properties). Optionally, each region can have its own sub–middle layer that aggregates its cues before feeding the task-level middle layer. This design (a) reduces CPT explosion and supports learning, (b) implements plan recognition by letting many weak cues add up, and (c) allows discourse-history updates over turns. Strongly diagnostic cues can still connect directly to the output if justified.

On the back-end: He felt the in-house back-end was too simple and that prior attempts to tune it hadn’t helped enough. He pointed out that SRI’s system benefits greatly from online, unsupervised adaptation and large training sets, and suggested pushing our tandem features through SRI’s stronger HMM/decoder to see immediate gains—even before any major retraining. Longer term, he argued that results people will take seriously (e.g., on digits) require a stronger back-end and much more training data, so either retrain with far larger datasets or leverage a proven back-end with adaptation.

On storing data: He wanted to save everything we record—e.g., all far-field channels from the SmartKom sessions—so others can use it for acoustic studies, provided we have the disk space. Organizationally, he supported using the same infrastructure and tools for convenience, but clearly separating it from the “meeting” corpus in naming/directories and description; reading digits and human–computer dialogues shouldn’t be labeled as “meetings” in distributions, even if they live under the same tree internally.

On storage mechanics, he advocated practical, scalable steps: buy more disk (it’s cheap) and, if needed, another file server; keep bulk audio on non–backed-up volumes and perform a one-time tape archive to avoid overloading nightly backups; use the existing tape robot/NW-archive workflow; place rarely accessed data on the older server and high-traffic data on a faster new file server. He discouraged relying on CD/DVD due to media degradation and warned that administrative operations (chmod/chown) can inadvertently force re-backups.

The NDP pressed for federal leadership, national LTC standards, and removing profit from care. The Prime Minister and Health Minister acknowledged the failures, highlighted CAF deployments and federal funding, and said Ottawa would work with provinces to improve care, but emphasized provincial jurisdiction and stopped short of committing to a federal takeover, Canada Health Act coverage, or a ban on for‑profit LTC.

- Hon. Lawrence MacAulay on veterans’ policy debate: He welcomed public engagement by veterans and families on policies and programs, said the government is open to input, and reiterated the goal of providing the best possible compensation and supports, while noting veterans can never be fully compensated for their service.

She acknowledged seniors’ added costs (e.g., dispensing fees, deliveries), said total senior aid exceeds platform commitments, and indicated further work was ongoing, including for persons with disabilities.

They clashed because each role optimized for different priorities under shifting, sometimes unclear requirements.

- Parental control: Marketing promoted it as a headline differentiator (“take parental control to a new dimension”). The Project Manager (PM) accepted the market appeal but insisted it be fast, optional, and simple at start-up to avoid user friction. The Industrial Designer (ID) questioned whether the development effort and technical complexity (where to enforce control, how to log in, constant signaling) justified the benefit and even suggested a separate device—creating scope and cost tension.

- Shape and materials: Marketing pushed “fruity,” soft, trendy forms and removable covers; PM worried about added cost and manufacturability, and later pressed for simpler single-curve options. ID weighed ergonomics (thumb reach, left/right-handed use), durability, and feasibility (double-curve, flip-up screen) and warned rubber can look “cheap” even if protective.

- Color/branding: Marketing favored a dark-blue base with bright accents; PM wanted strong brand recognition (even “yellow” cues). ID cautioned that multiple color options increase cost.

- Front controls: Marketing wanted a sleek look (flat/hidden buttons). PM argued for fewer, obvious TV-only controls to meet time-to-market and cost (no LCD, no speech). - Wireless/technical choices: ID briefly entertained wired control for cost; PM and Marketing rejected it as unappealing. They also debated infrared, voice recognition (Marketing liked the novelty; PM flagged cost/timeline; ID cited feasibility), and power (battery vs kinetic vs solar), again trading off innovation vs reliability, cost, and size.

In short, disagreements arose from role-driven trade-offs—market differentiation and style (Marketing), simplicity, cost, and schedule (PM), and ergonomics, robustness, and feasibility (ID)—amid evolving scope and incomplete cost data.

Marketing structured the evaluations as group scoring exercises grounded in sales goals and user research. They proposed shortlists of measurable criteria, had the team rate each concept on numeric scales (first a simple 1–5 style average, later a 1–7 scale where 1 = true/positive and 7 = false/negative), and then averaged the scores to compare alternatives and guide feature decisions.

The specific criteria they brought forward included:
- Look and feel/fanciness: aesthetic appeal, form, materials, and tactile “spongy” feel.
- Innovation: presence of novel features (e.g., LCD, speech recognition, find‑my‑remote/locator), not just cosmetic design.
- Ease of use and learnability: simplicity for new users, avoiding clutter, clarity of controls.
- Functional completeness and usefulness: the right functions without too many; whether teletext, subtitles, channel entry, etc., are covered logically.
- Fit to the target demographic (20–40): whether features and styling appeal to that audience.
- Alignment with company motto/brand and fashion trends: recognisable corporate image (logo/colours), “fashion in electronics,” and the fruit/vegetable trend with interchangeable covers.
- Cost/feasibility: staying within the €12.50 build target (and ~€25 retail), testing whether features like an LCD or advanced chips could be afforded.
- Ergonomics/RSI: comfort, grip, one‑handed operation, material choices to reduce strain.
- Findability when lost: options like LEDs, alarms/“screaming,” or locator aids.
- Willingness to pay: whether the concept would justify the €25 price point.

Using these criteria and averaged scores, Marketing steered decisions such as dropping the LCD and speech recognition to hit cost, while keeping design/brand appeal and ease of use central.

- Transcription: Active and expanding. Five meetings in the initial “set one” are done; staff was thinned by attrition but two new transcribers were hired with a third planned, keeping a lean team of about five to six. Workflows now include automatic segmentation cues (beep–digit–beep), and Thilo’s segmenter is being used to move off hand-segmentations. A status spreadsheet (date, speakers, duration, completion) is being compiled for the Meeting Recorder web page. About 11 hours have been fully transcribed and are being cleaned, channelized, and normalized (numbers, acronyms, nonspeech tags). A bleep/approval process is being set up: participants will review transcripts and can request excisions; email approvals are acceptable, with passworded web access available when needed.

- Recordings: Ongoing and sizable. One report lists approximately 62 hours collected as of the 14th; another later update cites roughly 32–35 hours (including digits). Additional meetings (ICSI groups, front‑end meetings, others) are being added; a 45‑minute gold set and ~10 hours are being packaged for IBM transcription. Goal is to be in “production mode” by the July DARPA meeting.

- Intermediate categories and the SPG schema: The SPG (Source–Path–Goal) design is drafted but not finalized. An “action schema” layer (e.g., Enter/View/Approach) will sit alongside an SPG image‑schema instantiation, with explicit cross‑links (IDs/XPath) to bind roles (e.g., Enter’s goal to SPG’s Goal). Multiple schemas per utterance are allowed (e.g., SPG travel plus a commercial “buying” schema). Constraints (e.g., via XForms) are envisioned; enforcement is not yet mandatory. There is an open design question about organizing categories “under SPG” versus “under action,” and XML examples were promised for the next meeting. The aim is a rich action description (RAD) that can support intention-level inferences without forcing phrasings.

- Duty to promote public awareness (Group 1): The Deputy Minister tabled amendments 1 and 4 to place a duty on Welsh Ministers to provide information and raise awareness of the change in law abolishing the defence of reasonable punishment. She confirmed a high‑intensity, six‑year awareness programme from Royal Assent. She asked Members to reject amendments 1A–1E, arguing they were unnecessary or overly prescriptive: naming specific audiences (e.g., visitors) could skew priorities; adding “understanding” adds nothing beyond “awareness”; specifying content (parenting support, how to report concerns) should be developed by the expert stakeholder and parenting groups, not fixed on the face of the Bill; children’s awareness is already addressed through Ministers’ existing due‑regard duty to children’s rights; safeguarding remains “everyone’s business.”

- Reporting on the effect of the legislation (Group 2): Through amendment 2 (and 5), she put a statutory post‑implementation review duty on the face of the Bill, describing a continuous programme after commencement: regular attitudinal surveys and a task‑and‑finish group to establish robust data capture and assess service impacts. She opposed amendments requiring a pre‑commencement evaluation of the awareness campaign, citing the need for certainty on the commencement date and existing plans to assess effectiveness. She agreed to consider at Stage 3 changing “publish” to “lay before the Assembly,” to consult the committee on the scope, and to explore an interim report before the five‑year post‑commencement report; she will also update the EM and RIA.

- Regulation‑making powers/commencement (Groups 3 and related): Because she fixed commencement at two years after Royal Assent (amendment 7), she re‑inserted a technical power (amendments 3 and 6) to make transitory, transitional or saving provisions for section 1’s coming into force. She said wider regulation‑making powers were unnecessary, noted CLAC’s view that no Assembly procedure was appropriate, but agreed to keep this under review and discuss ahead of Stage 3.

- Long‑term trends in standards and attainment: Ministers acknowledged trend-tracking is harder because performance measures have been deliberately changed to curb gaming and refocus on learners’ interests. Progress is now judged through a broader evidence set: Estyn reports, evolving school categorisation (used as risk/triage, not league tables), national exam data, PISA, and new interim measures such as capped 9 and the “third‑third‑third” analysis to ensure all learners count (not just C/D borderliners). A stronger culture of self‑evaluation is being built via the National Evaluation and Improvement Resource, co‑constructed with Estyn, OECD and practitioners. For schools causing concern—especially in the secondary sector—the Government is piloting a multi‑agency model (school, LA, consortium, Estyn, WG) to intervene earlier, track fundamentals (leadership, T&L), and secure sustainable, not “quick‑win,” improvement.

- Role of Qualifications Wales (per Philip Blaker): QW is the independent regulator. It approves qualification specifications and sample assessments, regulates awarding bodies (e.g., WJEC), and safeguards fairness in grading—especially during change—through prescribed awarding methods such as comparable outcomes. QW also scrutinises reform timelines to ensure system readiness, aiming to avoid compressed schedules that previously hindered resource and implementation timetables. Strategically, QW is exploring a shift from specification‑tied textbooks toward broader curriculum resources.

- Timescales for addressing the lack of exams: On QW’s clear advice, the summer exam series is cancelled. Year 11 and 13 learners will receive fair grades based on a range of evidence (including existing externally assessed units and moderated centre input), with UK‑wide moderation to protect standards. WJEC/QW will issue detailed guidance to centres imminently, with an intention to keep to the usual August results timetable if operationally possible. Decisions on AS (Year 12) and some vocational/technical awards are being finalised, with a presumption to award where continuous assessment permits and to avoid disadvantaging progression.

Members repeatedly highlighted that “good practice” does not spread consistently across Wales. Variation stems from uneven leadership and self‑evaluation, differing regional consortia approaches, and inconsistent use of data and evaluation. Estyn reported that while strong schools share practice well, too many rely on short‑term fixes (e.g., KS4 catch‑up) rather than sustainable pedagogy, and many heads lack confidence with foundation phase principles. Good practice networks exist (e.g., foundation phase, maths/science), but coverage and impact vary. The “middle tier” (LAs/consortia) remains mixed: roles can blur, challenge/support balance differs by region, and some LAs underuse intervention powers. Community‑focused models and multi‑agency work are promising, yet not universal.

Implications for childcare services mirror these disparities. Provision and take‑up vary by geography, historic LA decisions, and local demand; urban/rural costs and traditions (e.g., informal family care) compound differences. Welsh‑medium capacity is uneven, requiring targeted growth (new cylchoedd meithrin) and workforce upskilling. Joint CIW/Estyn inspections aim to secure quality across non‑maintained settings, but staffing (including Welsh language skills) is a constraint.

Delivering the childcare offer at scale therefore needs:
- Clear, consistent national frameworks with local delivery: co‑location of childcare and early education, aligned with WESPs, and capital to fill gaps.
- A robust workforce plan (training, recruitment, Welsh language) and stronger evaluation to know what works and scale it.
- Administration that reduces burden and ensures equity (centralised eligibility checks; vigilance on add‑on charges so low‑income working families aren’t priced out).
- Targeted support where costs are higher or capacity thinner, while preserving a simple, transparent core offer.

Without these, Wales will see continued postcode variation in access, quality, and language choice for families.

The team aligned on components that are available now and feasible to manufacture. Electronics will use the standard TA11835 IR remote chip driving an IR LED, with silicone-based printed circuit boards. Two boards will be used (one per flip section) linked by wiring; a standby mode and optional button backlighting (auto-off after 5–10 seconds) were proposed to conserve power.

Power options were reviewed extensively. AA/AAA cells were deemed bulky; a “dynamo” wind-up was rejected; solar charging was considered expensive, fragile, and unreliable under indoor light. The preferred solution is kinetic charging (as in automatic watches) feeding a small watch-style cell—compact, low-draw, and realistic for intermittent remote use. No separate rechargeable pack is available or required under this approach.

Case materials and finish: the factory can supply plastic housings and rubber components. Plastic was chosen for the main shell due to cost, durability, and freedom to mold non-boxy, curved forms compatible with a flip design. Titanium was rejected (cost, limited shapes, scuffing); wood was considered impractical. A removable rubber sleeve over the plastic body provides the “spongy” feel, grip, drop protection, and easy style refresh. Skins will ship in fruit/vegetable-inspired colors (not literal shapes), with scope for varied textures/patterns.

Interface design: a flip form factor with a monochrome LCD touch GUI on the top half for configurable controls, and physical anti-RSI rubber buttons on the bottom half for frequent actions (volume/channel) in a familiar layout. A stylus is optional; finger use is primary.

Finding the remote: a voice-response locator (“Where’s the remote?”) will be included if the company’s in-house speech module is affordable; otherwise, a simpler beeper is the fallback. A docking/port alarm was discussed but not finalized.

Final model: The professor emphasized that spectral subtraction and Wiener filtering are fundamentally the same family of noise-suppression methods, differing mainly by an exponent (power vs. signal-domain criteria). Many implementation choices matter as much or more—FFT-bin vs. mel-band processing, time/frequency smoothing, and over-subtraction. The team converged on a single unified codebase with options, but he urged fixing one configuration for now (best so far: FFT-bin Wiener) and stabilizing the pipeline. Current performance is close to the previous best despite not explicitly handling stationary noise; improving VAD and noise estimation is next, with a later stage adding a neural-net feature transform. Latency/causality should be guided by standards (130–250 ms budgets), but for now performance takes priority; future context can be curtailed if required.

Time series and reverberation: The group discussed modeling multiple parallel temporal feature streams with factorial HMMs, which keep parameters manageable and permit simple Viterbi-style inference. For reverberation, they highlighted Avendano’s modulation-spectrum approach: use long analysis windows (~2 s) so room response behaves like a convolution, then apply mean (DC) subtraction in the modulation domain and trade spectral for temporal resolution to produce recognizer-friendly features. They proposed extending this to time-varying room responses by estimating near–table-mic impulse responses via block least-squares echo cancellation and tracking how fast they change.

Pronouncing zero: For digit data, the professor noted systems should allow both pronunciations—“O” and “zero.” Earlier collection sheets sometimes forced one, but the current design intentionally elicits natural usage; transcripts can mark “OH” when appropriate. This reflects real-world variation and should be modeled accordingly.

The team agreed to introduce a fashion-forward but affordable universal remote with a clear emphasis on simplicity. Core concept decisions: power will combine a standard battery with kinetic recharging (shake/motion keeps it topped up); solar was rejected. The case will be double‑curved with a hard rubberized (non-bendable) exterior for grip and drop resistance, offered in flashy “fruity” colors with removable covers. To control cost, the interface will use pushbuttons and a simple chip (no LCD; no scroll wheel). A small, clean set of always-visible buttons will handle essentials (power, volume, channel up/down, favorites), while advanced settings (e.g., tuning, picture) will appear via an on‑screen menu.

Scope: the product will be a “light” universal remote able to switch between a few devices (e.g., TV, VCR/DVD, stereo/set‑top box), positioning below typical universal remotes on price but above bundled remotes on capability.

Parental control: included by default but optional to activate. The approach is profile-based (e.g., Parent, Child, Family) with quick access (simple code for adults), and restrictions by channel and/or time. No separate hardware add‑on; the functionality resides in the remote/TV interaction. Speed of use was emphasized so it doesn’t delay normal viewing.

Games: dropped. The group felt gaming on a remote adds complexity without supporting the viewing task.

Voice recognition: considered attractive for marketing and youth appeal, but it will be strictly secondary. If included, it will be a lightweight, small‑vocabulary command set (e.g., on/off, digits, volume) and only if it doesn’t significantly impact cost or reliability; ambient TV noise limits its practicality.

Overall, the design balances trendy look-and-feel with straightforward, fast operation and restrained feature set.

The committee probed two areas: possible rises in youth suicide during COVID-19 and sustained, equitable perinatal mental health care.

On youth suicide, Vaughan Gething acknowledged significant concern but said definitive conclusions can’t be drawn yet. He has commissioned the Welsh Government Delivery Unit to work with the National Advisory Group (including Dr Ann John) to review unexpected deaths occurring at the start of the pandemic to detect any spike in suicides among children and young people. A report was expected by the end of the month, after which the Government would update the committee. He stressed that crisis care for children and young people remains an essential, available service, with CAMHS capacity monitored weekly (covering staff sickness, referrals, and demand) and currently assessed as able to meet need. Telephone and online supports have been expanded and GPs continue to signpost to services.

On long-term special care for pregnant women, Gething reiterated the Government’s commitment to consistent perinatal mental health support across Wales and to protecting recent service improvements. Services have adapted to remote (phone/online) delivery where appropriate. He cautioned that work to create the previously committed in‑patient mother and baby unit capacity has been paused by the pandemic, potentially affecting timelines, but the commitment stands. He and the Chair noted a recent drop in mothers’ willingness to use mother and baby units due to fear and lockdown constraints; Gething emphasized this reflects behavior during COVID-19, not reduced need, and will not be used to downscale planned capacity. He praised staff commitment and underscored that perinatal mental health remains a priority throughout and beyond the pandemic.

- Implementation timeline and focus: The Strategic Delivery Group chaired by Prof. Dylan Jones has no fixed end date. It was set up about 18 months ago and is currently agreeing a plan with officials. Its purpose is to support the successful implementation of the new curriculum by clarifying roles and responsibilities across the “middle tier.” The Minister rejected any suggestion that the group might lose focus, saying it is very clear about eliminating duplication, setting clear demarcations, and ensuring partners can rely on each other.

- Views on pursuing harder improvements: Ministers and officials stressed moving beyond “low‑hanging fruit.” The new multi‑agency approach for schools causing concern focuses on fundamentals (leadership, teaching and learning, governance), the school’s capacity, and what extra support is needed, with a 6‑, 12‑, and 18‑month view to secure sustainable improvement. They also acknowledged that changing performance measures makes trend‑tracking harder, but insisted such changes are in learners’ best interests (e.g., a notable rise in English literature entries) and are worth the added challenge.

- PRU networking and transition arrangements: Witnesses reported markedly better networking within the PRU sector—more professional learning, reciprocal visits, and sharing of expertise with mainstream schools, especially around the curriculum. On transitions, Swansea described phased reintegration from PRU to school (often via part‑time timetables), close joint working with schools, continued post‑return support tapered over time, and recognition that reintegration is hardest at Key Stage 4, where planning shifts toward FE/college pathways. Torfaen highlighted a “team‑around‑the‑family” approach, tailoring wraparound support (including transport) to make reintegration viable. The overarching aim is coordinated, sustained support that avoids gaps where pupils can “fall between” services.

- Infra-red functionality: The team endorsed infra-red as the transmission method for the remote, describing it as the best option and emphasizing that the IR link must be “reliable and clear” so users aren’t “waving the remote around” or moving across the room to make it work. Making IR “very functional” was set as a general requirement. They tied IR performance to practical design choices: strong battery life/power delivery, a chip that encodes and drives the IR signal cleanly, and overall component quality (no “shoddy work”). Long battery life was highlighted as a supporting requirement, and there was openness to ideas like charging cradles later, but the core was dependable IR signaling from good power and electronics.

- Disposable income: When defining target users and pricing, the group noted that 15–25 year-olds often have relatively high disposable income due to fewer financial commitments (no mortgage, car, insurance), and that 25–35 year-olds are also attractive as they start jobs and buy “nice toys.” The proposed €25 retail price was considered affordable even for younger users. However, they also cautioned that some students may lack their own TVs or have older sets that could affect compatibility, so purchasing likelihood isn’t solely about ability to pay. They discussed possibly defining the target more by spending power and desire for fashionable, simple products than by strict age bands, while keeping production within the ~€12.5 cost limit. Overall, they saw younger, style-conscious buyers with discretionary spend as prime, provided the product remains affordable, usable, and broadly compatible.

- Using eligibility for free school meals (FSM) as a measure: The group regard FSM status as an imperfect but currently the best available proxy for socioeconomic need. They are exploring ways to refine it—monitoring the impact of Universal Credit, considering moving away from a single January snapshot toward a more flexible, multi‑year approach (an “Ever 2” style model), and consulting publicly before any change. They reject adopting “Ever 6” now due to an estimated £40m cost pressure. Guidance remains that PDG-funded individual interventions must target FSM‑eligible pupils, while whole‑school initiatives are acceptable only where evidence shows a disproportionate benefit for FSM learners.

- PDG’s impact on attendance and engagement for FSM pupils: They cite Estyn’s evidence that attendance has improved overall, but a significant FSM–non‑FSM gap persists. PDG is seen as a helpful lever that has “concentrated minds” and enabled evidence‑based actions. Examples include:
  - Primary: PDG‑funded “walking buses” led by teaching assistants to get targeted pupils into school.
  - Secondary: staff dedicated to working with families to tackle barriers; investment in school nurses and counsellors to coordinate with external agencies.
They note interventions grow harder with older pupils, and while permanent exclusion rates are not higher for FSM pupils, temporary exclusions are—requiring multi‑agency responses (well‑being, behaviour, ALN support) alongside PDG. Challenge advisers are expected to scrutinise schools’ PDG use and its measured impact on attendance/engagement, and new regional PDG advisers will spread effective practice.

Overall, PDG is judged to make a positive, context‑dependent contribution to attendance and engagement for FSM learners, but it is not a standalone solution; closing the gap needs sustained, multi‑agency effort.

On support vector machines (SVMs), the professor viewed them as a succinct, example-efficient alternative to more “brute force” models like neural nets or Gaussian mixtures. He likened SVMs to a principled form of condensed nearest-neighbor: instead of comparing to all training tokens, they keep only the critical support vectors near decision boundaries, yielding a reduced parameterization that can generalize better with modest data. For speech recognition use, he noted that although SVMs are inherently margin/distance-based rather than probabilistic, it’s feasible to convert SVM distances to posteriors (e.g., via a sigmoidal mapping or softmax-like calibration). He cited prior work from Mississippi State that did exactly this for speech recognition; their results were “OK” and interesting as a first attempt, but not breakthrough, and he was unsure whether rigorous large-task comparisons had established clear advantages.

Regarding speech-rate algorithms, the transcripts contain no specific discussion or endorsement from the professor. His remarks in these meetings focused on feature design for voicing (e.g., energy, spectral slope like R1/R0, zero-crossing counts historically), leveraging filter-bank/log-magnitude spectra, and practical recognizer issues such as pruning thresholds and front-end differences (PLP vs. mel-cepstra). He also suggested letting learning methods ingest richer spectral inputs rather than handcrafting overly clever single statistics. But he did not articulate any views, methods, or evaluations specific to speech-rate estimation or speech-rate–aware decoding in these sessions.

The professor draws a clear line between real reverberation/echo artifacts and how to mitigate them, and he also distinguishes “acoustic events” from traditional linguistic features. On echoes and reverberation, he notes that some “echo” heard in re‑synthesized audio can be pre‑echo–like artifacts introduced by non‑causal mean subtraction that averages over long windows (up to many seconds). This makes low‑energy regions especially vulnerable, because reverberation from high‑energy speech becomes most audible there. He cites earlier work showing that high‑pass filtering or operations that effectively suppress low‑energy portions (e.g., shifting and zeroing negatives, or a VAD‑like gate) can reduce the perceived reverberation without strictly adhering to an inversion equation. He advises a conservative strategy: if you must err, keep possible echoes rather than delete true speech. He also cautions that simple loudness increases should not help recognition unless they genuinely improve SNR; uniform gain changes in both train and test should be neutral.

On acoustic events, he favors bottom‑up, data‑measurable cues over top‑down, linguistically defined features. “Acoustic events” are salient signal happenings (e.g., onsets, rapid changes) that likely trigger neural responses and can be robustly detected. He encourages designing event detectors inspired by auditory processing (and informed by hearing‑aid research), potentially using probabilistic AND‑OR structures, and exploring phenomena like co‑modulation release. The idea is to develop reliable event detectors whose outputs can be fed into a recognizer (e.g., SRI) and evaluated in clean and noisy conditions, providing a pragmatic, signal‑driven complement to conventional feature sets.

The team aligned on a “simple, innovative, and easy-to-use” UI, prioritizing long-term usability over short-lived fashion trends. Benchmarking and expectations: TI-digits best published results are ~0.25% (many systems 0.5–0.75%; prior in-house <1%) in clean, close-talk conditions. Next steps include trying tandem features into the SRI backend and scaling training.

Data/format issues: allow natural “zero” vs “oh” pronunciations; forms group digits to elicit realistic reading. Within 1–2 weeks, channelized, post-edited transcripts should enable forced alignment and broader experiments.

The team saw rechargeable capability as a nice-to-have “gadget” that could help make the simple remote feel special, especially if paired with a base/dock that also lets users locate the remote via a beep or flashing light. The group agreed to standardize on close-talking, head‑mounted microphones and phase out the lapel mic, which was judged inferior and a source of cross-speaker variability that hurts transcription, recognition, and prosody work. Uniformity across speakers was prioritized over variety: the plan is to evaluate a more comfortable head-mounted headset (e.g., Crown CM‑311AE) compatible with the existing Sony wireless packs (via Sony’s proprietary connector and, if needed, custom-wired pigtails). They will buy one unit first for comfort and audio quality testing; if it proves better, they will purchase a full set (target ~9) so all primary participants use the same model.

Procedurally, they set placement guidance: position the boom toward the corner of the mouth, roughly a thumb to a thumb-and-a-half away, to reduce breath noise and improve SNR. Comfort is a requirement; a “field trip” to try alternatives was proposed.

On logistics, wireless vs. wired was deemed secondary; if wireless channels are limited, additional identical headsets can be recorded via wired inputs and time-aligned at meeting start. They will explore adding one more wireless channel (new transmitter/receiver) and consider a handheld pass-around mic for overflow speakers when attendance exceeds the fixed channels. Known hardware issues (some “Jimlet” jacks failing) must be addressed. The goal is a full complement of identical mics within the 16-channel limit, with any extra channels handled carefully.

In short: adopt uniform, comfortable head-mounted mics; document and enforce proper wearing procedure; test then bulk-purchase; expand/repair infrastructure as needed; and use a handheld overflow mic when necessary.
