The team converged on a TV-only remote that emphasizes simplicity, ergonomics, and a fashionable brand identity. Core functional scope was trimmed to the most-used actions—power, channel change, and volume—plus a single Options/Settings entry point that leads to submenus, consolidating low‑frequency functions. Teletext and multi-device control (DVD/VCR) were dropped by management. Infrared remains the transmission standard; a “find my remote” feature is prioritized via a small radio beacon and audible buzzer, because losing the remote was a top user complaint.

Design requirements are driven by a €25 retail price and ~€12.50 cost target. The casing should be durable, comfortable, and trend-forward: hard plastic with a rubberized feel or hard rubber, rounded/curved form that can stand on a table, and interchangeable or at least varied colorways (youthful “fruity” and muted “autumn” palettes). Buttons or on-screen elements should be large, tactile, and/or briefly backlit for dark rooms; glow-in-the-dark markings were discussed but backlighting was preferred for aesthetics and battery life. Corporate branding and the slogan “we put fashion in electronics” must be visibly incorporated. Voice recognition was attractive to younger users but deprioritized due to cost, complexity, and reliability in noisy environments.

Prioritized functional requirement: simple, reliable TV control of power, channel, and volume, plus findability.

Scroll feature: Two ideas were debated. A side-mounted scroll was considered less handy; instead, an iPod-like touch wheel on the face was explored for rapid channel browsing and possibly volume, toggled by a center select. The group agreed scrolling aids long lists (e.g., setup/channel search), but with few top-level options, direct on-screen buttons and a Back control are faster. Finalization of the touch-wheel vs. pure touch-screen navigation was left open, with cost and usability testing to decide.

- Upcoming meeting focus and plan: The Project Manager will open by confirming everyone received the minutes and then present newly e‑mailed project requirements. The team will make decisions on the core remote-control functions, explicitly aligning them with the User Requirements Specification: (1) user needs/desires; (2) functional design (what effects the device should deliver); and (3) working design (how it achieves those effects). Priorities to discuss include keeping the interface simple and fashionable, emphasizing high-frequency tasks (channel/volume) over infrequent settings, ensuring strong IR performance, and considering an LCD only if it doesn’t add complexity. Branding must reflect the company image (yellow/black, “we put fashion in electronics”). Options on the table: a slide/fold-out panel for advanced functions, a “find my remote” feature, long-life power or a charging cradle, and whether voice recognition fits the budget and target market.

- Marketing’s view on repetitive strain injury (RSI): Marketing reported that users are frustrated by difficult-to-learn remotes and raised RSI concerns (repetitive strain/carpal tunnel). Their guidance is to design for ergonomics and reduce repetitive, awkward actions: fewer, larger, well-placed buttons for the most-used functions; “less is more” to limit strain; and a form that “feels like the way they’ll use it” to avoid hand injuries.

- Group reflection on prior meetings and progress: The team felt productive given time limits, with technology aids helpful (prebuilt slides), but noted information flow dropped later, some role confusion, and that budget constraints curtailed creativity (e.g., cutting solar panels). They converged on simplicity-plus-fashion, a main interface with a concealed advanced panel, and debated voice recognition (ultimately viewing it as a key differentiator if cost permits). Overall, learning curves (e.g., slide-out) seemed acceptable, and future higher-budget variants remain a possibility.

- Lab test findings on buttons: In usability tests with 100 users, participants said current remotes have too many small, unnecessary buttons and don’t match real use. Users reported they only use about 10% of buttons. The most-used controls are channel and volume, with power used infrequently. Frequency data highlighted channel selection as by far the dominant action (e.g., “channel selection ~168 times per hour,” volume also high; power ~1/hour; teletext low). Users want a simpler, “snazzy but simple” design focused on these core controls, with numbers 0–9 retained, minimal settings (ideally via a single Menu/Settings entry), and larger, easier-to-hit buttons (especially a large power button).

- Finder/call button discussions: The group agreed a “find my remote” feature is important. They rejected clap/whistle gimmicks and favored a dedicated “call” button on a small transmitter stuck to the TV (or integrated by the TV maker). Pressing it should make the remote audibly beep; a light could be added but sound is primary because a hidden remote might not be visible. Radio was preferred over IR for the locator because IR needs line-of-sight. A charging base with a finder button was discussed but seen as adding cost; the standalone sender is preferred.

- Button design and location function details: The team favored a minimal layout: larger power, channel and volume as primary, numbers retained, and either a small joystick or iPod-like touch ring plus two function buttons (Menu and OK). One-handed, thumb-first ergonomics were emphasized. For the locator, the remote would contain a radio receiver and buzzer; the TV-side sender provides power and triggers the alert.

- Lighting adaptive options: The team agreed to drop lighting-adaptive features as unnecessary/complex and not market-driven, deferring such ideas to future products.

- DAT and external corpora: The team noted the Santa Barbara/LDC conversational corpus was likely recorded with DAT recorders and far‑field mics. They plan to obtain it (essentially free) to examine its simple discourse-oriented transcription format and to explore domain/adaptation value for meeting ASR. They acknowledged using it would only make sense if someone can work on acoustic/language model adaptation from that data to meetings; questions remain about channels (two vs multiple DATs).

- Power cables and room wiring: They are building table boxes that distribute headset/PZM mics and supply low‑voltage power, with front‑panel LEDs indicating a “live” box. Cabling will be bundled in sleeve and routed as a “speed bump” across the table; 16 total channels are available, with flexible mapping via simple plug-in connectors. Risks discussed: someone unplugging a powered leg with no upstream notification. They’re also considering a cleaner cabinet for the mixer and wireless laptop control (WaveLAN/Airport) to monitor levels, keeping the room tidy; the same design could be replicated at UW without wireless to save cost.

- Capturing subject intention: To elicit natural language without prompt-echoing, subjects will select their own high‑level tasks (shopping, sightseeing, film processing) and annotate a tourist map (no textual prompts carried into the session). Pictures were considered but rejected as labor‑intensive/distracting; a light text+icon hybrid remains possible. They aim for unambiguous mode labeling (Enter/View/Approach), while allowing multiple concurrent intentions (e.g., go to a bakery + buy food). Representation will use XML with linked schemas: Source‑Path‑Goal, force/caused action, and commercial events, with cross‑references/IDs and potential XPath/XForms constraints.

- Analysis approaches: For audio/transcripts, they’ll: (1) minimally edit orthographic transcripts; (2) “channelize” to per‑speaker tiers and add extra tiers for room/no-ownership noises (e.g., breaths, door slams); (3) use presegmentation (speech/non‑speech) and SRI forced alignment, then manual boundary corrections on diverse short excerpts; (4) seed automatic labels using rich pronunciation variants. For recognition baselines, train on TI‑digits and compare close‑talk vs distant mics, expecting initial degradation on distant channels.

General specification: The team prioritized a simple, ergonomic remote focused on the most-used functions (channel up/down and volume), with large, easy-to-press buttons and minimal clutter. Infrared was chosen as the transmission method. A docking station was favored to recharge standard batteries and to host a “find-remote” beeper button; kinetic charging was rejected as impractical, especially for older users. Teletext was dropped entirely. Voice recognition was also set aside due to weak demand among older users and cost/complexity at the target price.

Case design and form: Manufacturing could deliver flat, single-curved, or double-curved shells. The group leaned toward a single-curved body for better ergonomics and to give the display (when used) a readable angle. The remote will lie flat (not stand), with the power button kept in the conventional top position and the display—when included—on top. RSI concerns informed placing core controls where the thumb naturally rests; left/right mirroring and flip-over concepts were discussed but rejected for simplicity.

Decision on changeable cases: The team agreed to produce one standard core remote with interchangeable covers, adopting a “Nokia-style” shell system. This enables a wood-look option and a plastic/grey-black option (and future styles) without redesigning the internal hardware. It also creates a small accessories market (sell additional covers).

Design changes over time: The small LCD and a jog-dial were initially proposed to surface advanced functions; to meet the tight cost cap (~€12.5 build), the LCD and advanced chip were ultimately removed, relying on on-screen TV feedback instead. Rubberized parts and backlighting were also trimmed for cost. Final direction: a fashion-forward, single-curved, simple remote, rechargeable via docking station, with interchangeable cases and clear emphasis on usability.

Huw David said any unintended consequences should be minimal if the Bill is implemented carefully and properly resourced. He stressed that implementation and cultural change are crucial, noting children’s social services are already overstretched and must remain focused on serious harm and neglect while expanding early intervention and family support. He emphasized the system should not criminalise parents for low-level incidents; instead, there must be a proportionate response by police and social workers, alongside accessible parenting support so families are helped rather than penalised.

On whether legislation is needed given changing norms, he argued yes. The state’s paramount duty is to protect children from harm, and physical punishment constitutes harm. Far from unnecessary interference, the Bill reflects a decades-long cultural shift in Wales in which most parents neither use nor support smacking. He added that a clear legal line helps vulnerable children who may be told by adults that smacking is acceptable; the law should remove ambiguity so children and professionals alike know where the line is, enabling children to seek help.

Regarding whether certain provisions should be explicitly stated in the Bill, particularly on awareness-raising, he initially noted Welsh Government’s commitment to run a campaign and was unsure a statutory duty was necessary. However, when pressed on clarity and funding, he endorsed putting a duty on Welsh Ministers on the face of the Bill to lead public awareness. He indicated this would help ensure the necessary resourcing and make the implementation more effective and publicly understood.

- Design and functionality: The “two-sided” concept was proposed as a way to serve two use modes: one side with a full set of advanced controls (e.g., DVD/VCR functions) and the other with a very simple TV interface (channel ±, volume ±, mute) for “grandma” use. The user-interface lead objected that a two-sided form would be awkward to manipulate and prone to accidental presses. Mitigations discussed included a sliding back/lockout, a flip cover, or a physical lock function so only one side would be active at a time. Despite these, the team leaned away from a two-sided device in favor of a single, simple, ergonomic TV-only remote with few large buttons.

- Evaluation: Their evaluation framework prioritized ease-of-use, minimal buttons, attractiveness, and sellability. Against these criteria, a two-sided remote was seen as likely to be bulkier, more confusing, and costlier. The concept that advanced to scoring (a single-sided, minimal-button design) achieved a strong average score (~1.88 on a 1=true/good to 7=false/bad scale). The two-sided idea was not taken forward to formal scoring.

- Market range: Early talk included multi-device control and multiple user segments (children, elderly), but management constrained scope to TV-only and required corporate colors/branding. They favored one core model (with possible cosmetic covers) to hit an impulse-purchase retail price of about €25 and a build cost under €12.50.

- Technical requirements: They wanted durability and findability across concepts. For shock-proofing, they discussed either hard molded plastic (reinforced) or a rubberized casing and rubber buttons. For water-proofing, options included a fully water-resistant build or bundling an optional waterproof sleeve/box. Additional features considered: backlit/fluorescent buttons, a “find-me” beep/light, and a lock to prevent accidental input.

Group 3 dealt with the Bill’s regulation‑making powers linked to commencement. The Deputy Minister (Julie Morgan) explained that, because the Government was removing the Ministerial power to commence section 1 by Order and instead fixing a commencement date elsewhere, a technical replacement power was needed to make “transitory, transitional or saving” provisions when section 1 takes effect. Her amendment 3 re‑inserts that limited power on the face of the Bill, with amendment 6 bringing it into force the day after Royal Assent. She stressed this added no new policy powers, simply replicated what would have sat in a commencement order. Citing the Constitutional and Legislative Affairs Committee (CLAC), she said no Assembly procedure was recommended for this kind of power and the absence of formal procedure would not prevent scrutiny of ministerial decisions.

Suzy Davies challenged the characterisation of the changes as merely technical. Through probing amendment 3A, she argued that, given new duties around awareness‑raising and reporting, Ministers may need broader regulation‑making powers than the narrow transitory/transitional/saving power, and that any such instruments should be subject to Assembly procedure (negative or affirmative) to ensure scrutiny. She noted the power now sits within the substantive section 1 rather than a separate commencement provision and questioned whether the Government would, in practice, need wider implementing regulations to deliver policy (for example, aspects of the awareness campaign or reporting framework). Amendment 3A was tabled as a “holding” measure to prompt discussion before Stage 3.

The Deputy Minister replied that wider powers were not considered necessary but agreed to keep the matter under review and to discuss it with Members ahead of Stage 3, acknowledging unforeseen links with other legislation might emerge. Suzy Davies moved 3A, which did not carry; the Government’s amendment 3 proceeded.

- Purpose and scope: The middle tier—regional school improvement consortia, local authorities, Estyn, and Welsh Government—coordinates support, challenge, and implementation between schools and central policy.
- Shift to support and self-evaluation: Development of a national evaluation and improvement resource (with OECD and Estyn) to build robust, system-wide self-evaluation; Estyn engaged as part of solutions, not only inspection.
- Early identification and multi-agency response: New panels (school, LA, regional consortia, Estyn, WG) use broader intelligence (e.g., staff sickness, complaints, HR usage) to intervene earlier and secure sustainable improvement, especially in secondary schools.

- Universal adoption (Welsh Baccalaureate): “Universal” was defined as universal availability and entitlement, not a blanket obligation. The aim is for the Bac to become the norm post‑16, with flexibility where it is not in a learner’s best interests (e.g., wellbeing, specific needs). Ministers will rely on clearer performance measures, strengthened professional learning, and improved guidance/communications (including to FE) rather than pausing rollout. Where institutions insist all learners take it, guidance may be clarified to ensure justified exceptions.

- Advantages of the Higher Education (Wales) Act 2015: The Act was intended to (1) regulate Welsh HE providers in a loans‑based funding era, (2) safeguard public benefit from public funding, (3) maintain fair access, and (4) protect institutional autonomy. It gave HEFCW new intervention powers, enabled proportionate regulation tied to public funding, and—together with ministerial remit letters—supported national priorities (e.g., living wage, ethical procurement, transparency on senior pay, mental health initiatives). It preserved autonomy while allowing oversight, and worked alongside established QA arrangements (QAA/Estyn).

- Weaknesses and lessons: Evidence was mixed on whether all four objectives were fully met. HEFCW described powers as cumbersome for swift, preventative action and lacking sufficiently graduated steps between “soft” engagement and severe sanctions. Fee and access plans were seen as bureaucratic, input‑focused, and too short‑term (annual), with limited confidence in impact; a shift to multi‑year, outcome‑focused agreements is planned. The Act’s charity requirement limits regulation of some private/alternative providers; it does not permit regulation of most postgraduate fees and offers limited levers on part‑time fees (though no urgent need was identified). It focused on individual institutions rather than incentivising collaboration, did not directly tackle governance weaknesses, and created complexities in QA responsibilities across FE/HE. Overall, the Government will replace the Act via the PCET Bill, embedding outcome agreements, more flexible/regulatory gradations, stronger collaboration, future‑proofing (including for TNE/private provision), while retaining institutional autonomy.

The team formalized evaluation as a quick, repeatable scorecard derived from earlier user requirements. Marketing (Cat) presented the framework: a 1–7 scale (1 = strongly meets/true; 7 = does not meet/false), with criteria originally labeled A–D but expanded into a checklist. Each member scored independently; results were averaged to guide decisions and flag risks.

Key criteria and discussion points:
- Match to user behavior and ergonomics: Strong for right‑handers; left‑hand bias and flip‑open handling noted as risks to flag for management. RSI concerns mitigated by soft materials and minimal primary buttons.
- Intuitiveness and learnability: Basic functions clear, but departures from the standard 3×3+1 number layout and the scroll wheel introduce a learning curve. They separated “easy to use” from “easy to learn.”
- Functionality vs simplicity: Core TV tasks (volume, channel, power) prioritized; menus and multi‑use buttons cover advanced features. Simplicity generally scored well; complexity kept off the surface.
- Fashion/brand fit: Fruit/vegetable inspiration (potato/banana), corporate colors (yellow/black), and visible logo evaluated positively for distinctiveness and appeal, with alternates for conservative users.
- Innovation/technology: Components are familiar, but application (form factor, scroll input, base station/locator) seen as fresh enough; not bleeding‑edge.
- “Don’t lose it” feature: Color/shape help; electronic locator debated. Cost trade‑offs led to a simple beeper over a pricier speaker; RF locator tied to base station in later concept.
- Market fit and purchase intent: Mixed—stronger among younger, trend‑oriented users; some resistance to overt “banana” styling.

Outcomes: mid‑range averages reflecting good basics with learnability and handedness risks; action items included possible mirrored (left‑hand) variant, clearer number layout/labels, user testing (focus groups), and cost-trimming swaps to stay within the €12.5–€25 target.

- CDs for backup: Participants were skeptical about using recordable CDs/DVDs as archival media. Burned discs were reported to degrade in as little as 1–3 years (often failing unpredictably), and even pressed CDs can degrade over time. Conclusion: do not rely on CDs as the only copy. Preferred plan is to keep data on inexpensive non–backed-up disks and perform one-time archival to tape (using the existing tape robot/NW archive). Re-burning CDs yearly was floated but seen as impractical. They also discussed adding more disk capacity and possibly a new file server; tapes remain the long-term archive.

- Probability computation: For inferring the user’s navigation intention (Enter, View/Vista, Approach/Tango), they proposed Bayesian belief networks with intermediate nodes per information source (discourse, ontology/entity properties, user model, situational context). To avoid huge CPTs, they favored combining “expert” sub-decisions via weighted voting (averaging) and, more generally, a mixture-of-experts with a hidden selector (H) that chooses which expert to trust per case. They emphasized avoiding loops, decomposing features, and possibly learning weights/structures if data suffice; otherwise hand-setting priors. Tools considered included JavaBayes and Kevin Murphy’s toolkit, with features/data represented in XML.

- Experimental setup for the computer navigation system: A Wizard-of-Oz lab study simulates a mobile tourist assistant. Subjects view a 3D/QuickTime scene of Heidelberg, are told the system knows their GPS position, and complete tasks (e.g., get to a place to buy stamps; take a picture). Mid-session the “system” crashes, and a human operator continues, yielding both human-computer and human-human dialogues in one session. Audio is captured in an instrumented room with synchronized close-talking and multiple far-field microphones to support both linguistic and acoustic research. The system aims to distinguish Vista/Enter/Tango, factoring in object type, opening times, and time of day.

- Symmetrical buttons on both sides: The team rejected mirroring channel and volume controls on both edges because it would hurt ease of use. Marketing noted it was technically possible but would likely reduce simplicity; the Project Manager explicitly said usability would be “a lot more difficult,” and the UI lead agreed. When a flip-over design was floated as an alternative, the PM concluded the basic functions were simple enough that even left‑handed users wouldn’t struggle, so they kept a conventional, single-sided layout.

- Right- and left-handed versions at the prototype presentation: When the PM observed the prototype might necessitate separate right‑ and left‑handed models, the UI lead said producing both was feasible. However, Marketing and the Industrial Designer argued a dedicated left‑handed unit wasn’t necessary: families typically share one remote, left‑handers commonly use right‑handed mice without issue, and this device only requires pressing buttons. The Industrial Designer added they could offer both versions, and Marketing acknowledged that as an option, but the discussion ended without a commitment to dual SKUs. The PM moved on, praising the concept rather than mandating separate models. In later scoring, the team even noted it would score best if both handed versions existed, but otherwise accepted that the current design is somewhat right‑hand–biased. Overall, the sentiment leaned toward keeping a single model and treating a left‑handed variant as optional rather than a core requirement.

The team faced a strict production-cost ceiling of €12.50 and concluded the initial concept was “way above” that. They explored savings and, in one early pass, showed costs could drop to about €12.40 by removing both the solar cells and voice recognition. In the final redesign, they prioritized keeping the LCD and essential pushbuttons for usability. Dropping voice recognition alone still left costs near €13, so they also removed the “special” yellow color from the base unit, standardizing it to black/grey to hit the €12.50 target.

They debated materials and form. Plastic would be cheaper, but marketing and the PM argued to retain the rubber “spongy” casing for durability, grip, and differentiation. They also chose to keep the distinctive “banana” curve to stand out, while acknowledging that more exotic options—titanium casing, double-curved housing, solar power, and a kinetic energy source—were too costly or conflicted with other goals and were therefore abandoned. With voice recognition gone, related elements (e.g., a program/training button) became unnecessary.

Their cost-reduction strategy centered on: removing high-cost features (voice, solar), standardizing finishes (base black/grey), minimizing unique parts, and avoiding exotic housings. To preserve trendiness without burdening the base cost, they proposed optional, paid interchangeable covers, allowing customization while manufacturing a single, low-cost core product. The team agreed the LCD delivers more value than voice recognition at this price; if customers want voice, it would require a higher price or dropping the LCD. Management’s mandate was clear: stay under €12.50 or the project is a no‑go, so the final package reflects those trade-offs.

Pros
- Strong market appeal: Research indicated a “vast majority” would pay more for more intuitive control like voice, making it a potential selling point and differentiator.
- Fits target users: The team leaned toward a 15–35 (esp. 25–35) demographic that’s gadget-friendly with disposable income; voice scored highly with them.
- Perceived simplicity/high-tech: Delivers a high-tech feel while promising easier operation; could help keep the surface uncluttered by replacing some buttons.
- Accessibility: Could benefit users with physical disabilities.
- Optional/controllable: Can be implemented as an opt-in feature (activate/deactivate), or limited to simple actions (e.g., power, mute), reducing risk of overcomplexity.

Cons
- Reliability concerns: Prior experiences showed poor performance (“yelling at the control”), suggesting tech maturity may not yet meet expectations.
- Cost impact: Likely expensive to integrate, challenging the target price point (~€25 retail) and overall cost constraints.
- Power/battery life: Microphone and processing increase power draw; could pressure battery life and complicate decisions about rechargeable vs. standard batteries.
- Transmission/ergonomics conflict: With IR, holding the remote near the mouth for speech may block line of sight to the TV, reducing reliability unless the design or transmission method changes.
- Time-to-market and complexity: Company cautioned against complexity; adding voice may delay delivery and divert focus from the core “simple TV-only” brief.
- Not universally suitable: Voice may be good for some functions and poor for others; the industrial designer urged defining functions first and avoiding lock-in to a single technology.

Battery options were weighed against size, cost, ease of use, and longevity. The Industrial Designer’s general requirements were a long‑lasting, low‑cost power source that enables a compact form factor and reliable IR transmission, with minimal user maintenance. He flagged most current remotes as “chunky” because of battery size and urged shrinking the power system.

Options discussed:
- AA/AAA cells: Cheap and ubiquitous; AAA can thin the device versus AA. However, he argued even AAA makes the housing bulky and compromises the sleek design goal.
- Coin/lithium cells: Much smaller, but he cautioned about matching power consumption and availability.
- Rechargeable pack + charger cradle: Pros—long runtime, no buying batteries, and the dock could host a “find my remote” beeper. Cons—added hardware/space and possible budget impact.
- Dynamo/wind‑up: Rejected as impractical and bulky (requires a handle).
- Solar: Would need visible panels, is fragile if dropped, less effective under artificial light/night use, and adds cost/visual clutter.
- Kinetic (self‑charging like a watch): Favored for novelty and practicality; motion charges a small “watch‑type” storage cell, which is adequate because a remote only sends brief bursts. No user action or battery purchases.

Conserving battery life: he proposed standby when idle and auto‑timeout on any keypad backlighting (e.g., off after 5–10 seconds).

Decision on battery type: The team chose kinetic charging with a small watch‑style storage cell, explicitly not AA/AAA, solar, or dynamo.

Why he recommended a charger (earlier) for the industrial working design: To meet the “long‑lasting, minimal maintenance” requirement and reduce battery replacement hassle, he endorsed a cradle like mobile phones use; it keeps the remote topped up and could integrate the locator beeper. As component constraints and design direction evolved, the team pivoted to the cleaner kinetic solution.

- To test whether there’s a publishable story: following Nancy’s advice (“you don’t know whether you have a paper until you write it”), they wanted to draft it and get Jerry’s feedback.

- Good venue fit: the target conference is explicitly interdisciplinary (cognitive, neural, psycholinguistic motivations for NLP), aligning with their construction-grammar approach, Bayes-net architecture (SUDO: Situation, User, Discourse, Ontology), and cognitively plausible design.

- Feasible scope for a short paper: they can present a focused “Where is X?” case as a position/architecture paper—outline parsing/understanding, show how discourse and ontology cues feed the Bayes net, and discuss intention uncertainty (info-seeking vs go-there) without needing full evaluation.

- Funding for the consortia: Williams backed routing in‑year professional learning money to schools via the regional consortia, not earmarking it centrally. She said challenge advisers and headteachers should diagnose local needs and target spend accordingly (including, where relevant, improving Welsh Bacc delivery). Energy source: The team surveyed multiple options—standard batteries (AAA vs. lithium), a rechargeable base, solar, hand‑dynamo, and kinetic. They rejected a bulky charging base to keep the remote small, and dropped solar because the soft, changeable covers would block panels. Early consensus favored a small, battery‑only unit (leaning toward lithium over AAA for weight and modernity). In the final costing session, they committed to kinetic power as the primary energy approach, identifying it as the key differentiator. (Earlier battery discussions informed size/weight targets; the final choice positions kinetic as the main source, with simple electronics.)

Technological innovation: Several ideas were explored—side scroll/push controls, full voice recognition, and a “finder”/locator. Full voice control was deemed complex, costly, and prone to false triggers, so they did not adopt it. The principal innovation finalized was kinetic energy. Secondary user‑experience innovations include illuminated buttons-on-press, tactile/shape cues, side-mounted channel/volume controls that require a deliberate press, and an ergonomic curved form with optional fashion covers.

Overall evaluation: Using a 7‑point scale, they assessed ease of use, fashion, feel, innovation, handedness, and likelihood of getting lost. The prototype was praised as comfortable, simple, and “cute/beautiful,” with strong fashion appeal (gunmetal/black base, customizable covers). Innovation was rated positively but not maximal (kinetic is new; other electronics remain simple). They noted a right‑hand bias (mitigations discussed) and judged it unlikely to get lost (size, visibility; locator considered). Costs fit the budget (<€12.50 components), and the team concluded the design is marketable and a “winner.”

- Technical issues: The team agreed to keep the design simple, robust, and low-cost. They favored infrared (IR) for universal TV compatibility and rejected Bluetooth because TVs don’t support it and it would add cost/complexity. Teletext support was dropped, and scope was narrowed to TV-only to hit time-to-market. They rejected LCDs, spinning/scroll wheels, and “chip-on-print” advanced electronics as too costly or RSI-unfriendly, preferring a low-cost PCB with simple rubber push-buttons. A 4‑way ring/rocker was considered for channel/volume. Likely buttons: power, channel ±, volume ±, full numeric keypad (still debated but leaning yes), plus a lock key; glow-in-the-dark/backlighting and a “find my remote” function were explored (audio beacon favored over lights, though complexity/cost needs checking).

- Energy source: Options surveyed included standard batteries, hand dynamo, kinetic/energy-harvesting (like watches), solar, and hybrids. The group converged on a spongy, double‑curved rubber, anti‑RSI case that can be squeezed (and even tossed) to harvest kinetic energy to top up internal batteries. Pure indoor solar was doubted; a hybrid solar/rechargeable or a cheap charging cradle were discussed as possible complements if costs permit.

- Project announcement email: The project manager said instructions/assignments (industrial design: look/feel; UI: layout/controls; marketing: requirements/positioning) would be sent by email between meetings, joked about “spam,” and noted further coordination with leadership; team members were told to expect an email with next steps.

- Sample sensor: The “just-developed sample sensor/speaker” (speech feature demoed with the coffee machine) was rejected. It offered programmable call-and-response rather than true command recognition, added cost, and didn’t aid TV control; a speaker in the remote was deemed unnecessary.

In the final meeting, the team reviewed the prototype, costs, and readiness for launch, then made a key scope decision to meet budget.

Key design/prototype points:
- Form and feel: Single-curved, rubber-coated, durable body with a soft, “spongy” grip; unconventional, more natural look. Optional multi‑color indicator light (can be disabled).
- Core controls: Always-on top deck with Power, Channel Up/Down, Volume Up/Down; a slide‑out panel provides advanced functions. Interchangeable “skins”/faces are feasible, with initial subdued options and potential for Apple‑style colors later.
- Voice recognition: Integrated mic/sensor console on the back; works reliably within intended room range and is positioned as the primary differentiator.

Cost and problems reviewed:
- Budget target was €12.50. After itemizing components (including a solar cell and back‑up battery), the build came in over budget (≈€16), contradicting earlier rough estimates.
- The solar/back‑up battery hardware was the main cost driver. Keeping solar without a back‑up introduced reliability risks (support/call‑center burden for the ~1% “no-light” scenarios).
- Usability: The slide‑out panel has a short learning curve but tests well once users acclimate. Multi‑color lighting could annoy some users, hence the off option. Availability and timing of additional “skins” remain to be finalized.

Decisions/outcomes:
- Drop the solar cell (and back‑up battery) for launch to hit cost targets; revisit solar when pricing improves.
- Make voice recognition the flagship feature; retain the rubberized, ergonomic form and optional aesthetics.
- Overall product evaluation: Meets functional and aesthetic goals; minor usability concerns are acceptable for release.

On-line normalization:
- PhD C implemented on-line normalization with two separate running means (speech vs. silence) driven by the VAD posterior, plus a variable time constant that adapts quickly at utterance start and then caps to continue slow adaptation. He observed the largest mean differences in C0 and especially C1; C1 shows “strange” speech–silence behavior across noises. Consistent with prior findings, normalizing C0 matters, while C1 normalization doesn’t help with the current scheme. He also tried per–mel-band noise-flooring by adding white noise ~15 dB below each utterance’s peak band energy: MFCCs became much smoother and clean/noisy channels looked similar; recognition was roughly unchanged. He found a major confound: LDA filters trained on noisy speech were suboptimal when testing mismatched; reverting to clean-trained LDA raised accuracy from 82.7% to 85.1%, arguing for standardized, fixed components during noise-compensation experiments.
- The professor urged analyzing error patterns (insertions/deletions, quiet vs. noisy) rather than only global WER, suggested exploring different noise-addition schedules, and emphasized standardizing unchanged system pieces.

Phase normalization:
- PhD F’s phase mean subtraction (long-term mean) produced “garbage.” Grad G found Matlab phase unwrapping made results worse than no unwrapping. Discussion shifted to operating directly in the complex domain and dividing out the average complex spectrum instead of log-domain subtraction, with cautions about complex-log scaling/Taylor expansions.

Opinions on phase normalization and quals:
- PhD C offered no strong position on phase normalization; his stance focused on cepstral (esp. C0) normalization and careful controls.
- The professor was skeptical of naive log-domain phase mean subtraction, open to complex-domain normalization done carefully, and broadly advocated rigorous, controlled evaluation. On quals, he did not set content but implicitly supported targeted “cheating” analyses (using oracle cues) to assess which intermediate categories aid recognition.

The group framed “important linguistic features” as low-dimensional, largely binary articulatory/phonological variables (e.g., sonorancy, voicing, nasality). Initial targets can come from canonical phone-to-feature mappings (e.g., TIMIT), but they prefer learning them more finely: per-band hidden targets estimated with EM (as in Saul’s sonorant detector), so the system can down‑weight unreliable evidence rather than forcing all detectors to train equally. They also discussed supplementing/validating targets via manual annotation by linguistics students or by clustering continuous articulatory measurements, recognizing that per-utterance feature truth is often hidden.

Feature streams: Robustness comes from multi-stream/multi-band processing. They described combining multiple feature streams (e.g., OGI features, low‑pass filtered variants, parallel MLPs, KLT projections), then summing linear MLP outputs. Conceptually, they favor a soft “AND” across feature detectors within a band and a soft “OR” across bands, with per-band target activity treated as hidden. This lets the system ignore noisy bands and exploit complementary evidence.

Noisy-ORs: For combining multiple cues into higher-level decisions (e.g., Enter–View–Approach actions), they advocated Heckerman-style Noisy-OR/related deterministic combination functions over full CPTs. Introducing intermediate Ei nodes (each “effect given one cause active, others in a default state”) reduces parameters from exponential to linear in the number of cues, handles missing observations gracefully, and aligns with multi-cue evidence combination (e.g., max-like Noisy-OR or weighted evidence sums). If tools (e.g., JavaBayes) don’t support this natively, they can generate CPTs from the combining function.

Transcription formalization: They standardized transcripts to support both ASR and feature detection: glossing colloquials (“cuz”→“because”), consistent disfluency tokens, acronym conventions, explicit tags for laughter/non‑vocal events/qualifiers, and clear separation of read numbers (NUMS) from spontaneous speech. Scripts produce ASR‑ready and analysis‑ready versions, providing reliable supervision and metadata for training and evaluating these feature detectors.

- System involvement in demos: The team converged on a multi-part demo. Core pieces include a THISL-based information retrieval front end (Tcl/Tk GUI) that indexes meeting transcripts and lets users query by keywords and click-to-play audio segments; possible merging with Transcriber for a unified interface. A prosody visualization piece (stylized pitch, features for turn/sentence boundaries) will be shown, ideally inside Transcriber or via X Waves; Windows compatibility is a constraint, with Snack/Tcl/Tk workable but version-sensitive. Target: have all pieces running by month-end, then port and stabilize on the professor’s laptop. For SmartKom, a minimal “concept-to-speech” path is running (brittle but demo-able); a broader institute talk is envisioned once it’s stable.

- Backups and collecting notes: Disk usage is near capacity. Plan: acquire more disks and keep meeting data on backed-up storage; also create NW archive copies for redundancy. Avoid relying on non-backed-up scratch or CD-Rs for backup. Short-term sharing of local drives is acceptable. For notes, CrossPads were tried (time-stamped notes) but suffered from pen noise and synchronization overhead; alternative options include assigning a scribe post hoc or lightweight PDA/wireless-button time markers for highlights and sensitive-content flags. Keep one CrossPad for experiments; returning the other is fine.

- Switchboard: Meetings show pervasive overlap; the group wants to quantify how much more overlap occurs versus two-party Switchboard calls (where backchannels dominate but earlier corpora made overlap hard to study). On recognition, Switchboard experiments showed PLP ≈ Mel performance, with ~1.5% absolute gain from system combination; plans include retraining MLPs using SRI alignments.

- Scheduling meetings going forward (professor’s view): Alternate focus between Meeting Recorder topics and recognition/system discussions (possibly biweekly). Stay flexible; if topics pile up, add another meeting. Coordinate the plan with Liz and Jane.

The committee was told that Welsh Government has ended plans to use HMRC to administer the Childcare Offer. Julie Morgan said the main driver was a principled policy choice: HMRC would constrain the flexibility needed to expand and adapt the Offer in Wales. Specifically, she wants the system to be able to include parents in education and training and to address cases such as families with no recourse to public funds—changes that would have to be handled locally, not through HMRC. She also highlighted a dependency risk: because HMRC’s platform underpins the English scheme, changes made for England could impede Wales’s ability to tailor its offer.

Morgan acknowledged there were Welsh language compliance issues too. While HMRC can provide a bilingual service under its scheme, detailed discovery work showed difficulties meeting the Welsh Ministers’ language standards across multiple interconnected IT systems (including handling Welsh characters and feeds from other UK departments). Although the previous Minister had assured the committee this would not be a problem, officials accepted this should have been bottomed out earlier.

Cost and value for money were additional factors. Jo-Anne Daniels said HMRC’s post-discovery costs were “significantly higher” than first indicated; the Government believes a Welsh local-authority model will be cheaper, keep investment in Wales, and deliver better support. The decision is to move from the temporary arrangement to a permanent, single national application administered by 10 lead local authorities (current admin grant c. £2.5m, ring-fenced), with total costs expected to be below HMRC’s proposal.

Morgan noted initial WLGA support for HMRC had shifted; local authorities now back the in-Wales approach, which they feel is closer to families and better able to manage complex cases. She thanked HMRC for a positive relationship but concluded the local model best meets Wales’s needs.

- Professor’s workshop comment: He recalled a workshop where everyone used a P-make–like dispatcher to blast jobs to all machines; with 25 people sending to 25 machines, the cluster ran less efficiently than if each person had just used a single machine.

- Team’s feedback on the person in Grenada: They identified Jose Carlos Segura (Granada) as a promising collaborator who has an implementation of Vector Taylor Series (VTS) techniques for modeling the clean-to-noisy cepstral transformation; they’re exploring working with him as part of combining enhancement/noise-compensation methods.

- Required elements in the new form arrangement: The system now uses two forms (a one-time speaker form and a digits-reading form). On the digits form, Time is listed before Date because Time is used to find the digit-reading segment in the meeting audio; Date is often pre-filled. The essentials the participant must fill out are Name, Email, and Time. Native language is collected; the “Region” field is being simplified (dropping “Northern,” keeping “Other,” possibly using freer self-description).

- Suggested belief-net structure: Move from a flat “all features → mode” design to a layered network: observed features (e.g., discourse cues like admission-fee talk, verb class, prosody, time of day, “closed,” “nice walls,” context) feed hidden intent/state nodes (e.g., on a tour, running an errand, in a hurry), which then predict the mode (Enter/Vista/Tango). In a later refinement, separate subnets (user, situation, discourse, ontology) feed a Go-there decision, with added user-finance nodes (thrifty/budget → financial state).

- Grad B’s opinion on the belief-net structure: The flat model was unsatisfactory; he favored introducing (even many) middle-layer nodes for concepts. He also questioned a strict separation between features and output, proposing some direct influence (e.g., “admission fee,” “closed,” “has door”) via an intermediate “wants to enter” node or even direct arcs to the mode.

Grad E’s aim was to make mean log-magnitude spectral subtraction practical for an interactive system (SmartKom) by avoiding look‑ahead. He tested using only past context (about 12 seconds) versus a centered window and found the performance drop to be tiny, which he viewed as encouraging for low-latency deployment. He also probed whether training-time mean windows must match test-time windows. Training with 12-second means but testing with shorter windows (≈4–8 seconds) hurt slightly (typically <0.5% absolute WER, occasionally ~0.8%), leading him to conclude that longer training windows don’t help if test-time context will be short; matching train/test window lengths or ramping up context over time may be preferable. He noted open decisions (e.g., speech vs silence frames in the mean) and saw further tuning as warranted, but overall regarded the approach as viable with modest, manageable trade-offs.

Grad A’s goal was diagnostic: to run “cheating” experiments that inject oracle knowledge about intermediate categories (starting with voicing) to quantify their value for recognition. In a hybrid setup, he planned to edit LNA files to zero out posteriors of phones incompatible with known voicing during given segments (and possibly renormalize among the remaining phones), starting with TIMIT phone recognition and extending to digits to study inter-phoneme events (e.g., stop→vowel transitions). He did not present results yet; his view is that these experiments would reveal which categories most improve recognition, informing future model design rather than immediately delivering a deployable system. He targeted completing these investigations by his qualifying exams.

User Interface’s stance:
- Fewer physical controls: Prefer a largely buttonless, touch-based LCD with clear, large icons, a dedicated Back/Options path, and only essential hard keys (notably Power). Advanced settings should be hidden in menus or behind a cover to keep everyday use simple, especially for older users.
- Control layout norms: Volume up/down arranged vertically; channel +/- horizontally (matching common mental models). Avoid side scroll wheels (they can be bashed where you grip the device); on‑screen selection is faster for small menus.
- Form and materials: Ergonomic “single‑curve” body that can stand in a charging dock; rubberized casing for grip and durability; company name visible on the front.
- Speech recognition: Support adding a visible microphone and simple voice commands; it’s lightweight to include and a differentiator.
- Radio waves: In favor of RF; interference can be mitigated by using specific unlicensed bands and embedding an identification/handshake code so neighbors’ remotes don’t conflict.

Final decision:
- Design: A single‑curved, rubber‑cased remote with a moderate‑size touchscreen, minimal hard buttons (Power prioritized), rechargeable batteries with a docking/charging stand, and company branding. Teletext is dropped; scope is TV‑only. Speech mic included as a highlight feature, with simple voice control.
- Signal technology: Proceed with infrared (IR) for cost and simplicity (off‑the‑shelf electronics), keeping RF as a future option.
- Budget use: Targeting the cost ceiling, the team will not spend additional budget on nonessential features. To control costs, extra scroll wheels are omitted and the body is flattened where possible to save roughly €2. Any remaining headroom is reserved; there’s “no point in spending money if we don’t have to.”

- Effect of noise on speech frequencies: He noted a prominent very‑low‑frequency component (~5 Hz, e.g., air‑conditioner/handling) in PDA mics. A mild high‑pass option (cutoff ≈20 Hz; slight effect up to ~100 Hz) is recommended; it does not harm even low speech frequencies and PZM mics already roll off there. With distant mics, indirect energy attenuates high frequencies and distorts temporal trajectories; the example used on the web was thus a poor illustration of reverberation versus additive low‑frequency noise.

- Noise addition vs convolution: The evaluation data are dominated by additive noise, while their legacy RASTA‑like (log‑domain) processing mainly addresses convolutional effects. He argued the system should explicitly handle additive noise in addition to existing robustness methods.

- Smoothing/temporal filtering: Their LDA/RASTA FIR filters act as modulation‑domain low‑pass smoothing centered around speech‑rate modulations (~5 Hz). However, these FIRs incurred large latency. Proper anti‑alias low‑pass filtering should precede any downsampling.

- FIR filters (latency): The original FIR bank caused ~200 ms delay. He endorsed replacing them with IIR (recursive) filters matched in magnitude response, cutting delays to ~64 ms (low band) and ~11 ms (high band), accepting slightly non‑linear phase because speech modulation cues are preserved.

- Dealing with additive noise: He advocated mel‑band spectral subtraction with SNR‑dependent over‑subtraction to limit musical noise, and on‑line noise estimation from nonspeech regions (via VAD, histograms/thresholding). This works best for stationary or slowly varying noise; non‑stationary noise is harder and raises latency/estimation trade‑offs. He cautioned that spectral subtraction can increase feature variance and interact poorly with on‑line mean/variance normalization and VAD; sequencing (e.g., VAD → subtract → normalize, or layered subtraction) should be tested. Overall, combine explicit additive‑noise suppression with their existing methods rather than abandon them.

The group defined the remote’s core function as a TV-only controller to keep cost and time-to-market down, focusing on the most-used actions: power, channel, volume, numeric entry, and mute. Teletext and TV settings (audio/screen/channel) would exist in sub-menus to avoid clutter. They debated an LCD/touch UI versus physical controls; one path favored a mostly touch-driven layout with customizable icons and minimal hard keys, while another argued LCD adds cost without feedback from the TV and preferred traditional controls. Across concepts, the “object” should be ergonomic for one-handed use (ambidextrous), mid-sized so it’s harder to lose, slim (~1.5 cm), and durable: plastic inner shell with a rubberized exterior for grip and drop resistance. A bright, “fruity” color line targets younger users, with optional classic covers.

On energy, the team explored kinetic (hand‑dynamo) and solar. Solar was rejected (night use), and kinetic was judged eco-friendly and marketable but over budget; they cut it to meet the ~€12.50 build target. The preferred solution is rechargeable batteries with a docking/charging cradle; some variants add a base “locator” to ping the remote.

They also developed a “roll through favorites” concept. A scroll wheel was debated for cost vs. uniqueness and usability. The agreed value case: let users program a favorites list (e.g., 01, 05, 38) and “roll” through those channels, with a mode switch to toggle between sequential channel up/down and favorites-only scrolling. Indicators (LED or backlit buttons) would show the active mode. They noted TV response speed variability but accepted it as a learnable quirk. In the higher‑end configuration, the team favored scroll wheel + cradle + locator as distinctive features.

- Demographic marketing strategy and design: The team chose an exclusive, premium positioning over mass-market, targeting primarily 18–35-year-olds, with pricing in the ~€35–€50 retail range (accepting lower margins if needed). To appeal to varied tastes within this demographic, they proposed customization: changeable faceplates/skins and multiple case colors/materials (e.g., wood/earth tones alongside silver/black). They also planned eco-friendly features (solar with backup battery) to attract environmentally conscious buyers and discussed piloting casing options pre-launch. A lifetime “normal-use” guarantee was floated to build trust for a new brand.

- Industrial Design × Marketing agreement on appearance: Both sides converged on a durable, double‑curved, rubberized, “organic” aesthetic with a soft, tactile feel; simple, familiar rubber buttons for core functions; and optional skins/faceplates. They aligned on offering several colorways and potentially non-traditional, “non‑remote‑looking” forms that look good on a table. Marketing’s early “silvers and blacks” suggestion evolved into shared support for natural/earth tones while avoiding sterile “surgical white.”

- Industrial Designer’s marketing-plan proposal: Lead with fashion and desirability—an iPod-like, instantly “wantable” object (“don’t care what it does, as long as it looks cool”), mitigate market risk via multiple case styles to suit different tastes, and differentiate with small novelties (e.g., visible-light signaling) and eco cues (solar).

- Marketing’s view of what’s marketable: They praised the prototype’s “where’s my remote” locator/base as immediately marketable. While calling a touch screen the most marketable headline feature, they deemed it too costly now. Paper contents:
- Section 1: Quantifies overlapped speech across four corpora using “spurts” (continuous speech segments with no pause >500 ms): Meeting Recorder meetings, Robustness meetings, Switchboard, and CallHome. It compares overlap by words and by spurts, with and without backchannels.
- Section 2: Measures how overlap affects ASR. By scoring only certified foreground-speech regions (via forced alignment), most extra error from overlaps (largely insertions due to background talk) nearly disappears, approaching the non-overlap error rate.
- Section 3: Analyzes “interrupts”: where second speakers begin relative to the foreground speaker’s sentence. Using punctuation-derived sentence boundaries and lexical tags (discourse markers, backchannels, filled pauses, disfluencies), interruptions cluster after pauses, discourse markers, backchannels, and filled pauses.

Key statistics reported:
- Meeting Recorder overlapped words ≈17–18%; Robustness ≈ half that (~9–10%).
- Switchboard and CallHome show similar overlap levels to each other; removing backchannels reduces Switchboard overlap only modestly (e.g., ~14% → ~11%).
- Overlap in two-party telephone speech is of the same order as multi-party face-to-face meetings.
- Noted speaker distribution example: in Robustness meetings, one participant contributed ~56% of the words.

- Agreement on training/testing the digits corpus:
  - Run the exact same SRI recognizer on the standard TI‑digits test set to get comparable numbers, and also test our in‑room digits. 
  - Evaluate far‑field performance by decoding the PZM/other room mics while using near‑field segment times (from transcripts or forced alignment) so the test set matches prior HLT conditions. 
  - Try both with and without adaptation/VTL; beware little per‑speaker data (may fake speaker IDs or modify scripts).

The group used a long-term mean subtraction in the re-synthesis pipeline (averaging over windows up to ~12 s and subtracting from the speech) to reduce stationary/channel effects—functionally similar to channel normalization/CMS. In SRI experiments on Meeting Recorder digits, this helped far-mic PZM data (WER improved from ~6% to ~4.5%) but hurt near-mic (from ~1.2% to ~2.4%), whereas HTK had shown near-mic gains.

Two main explanations were proposed:
- Redundancy with SRI adaptation: The SRI recognizer already performs channel adaptation (e.g., conversation- or utterance-side normalization, VTLN/MLLR). Mean subtraction may have provided a boost in HTK (which lacked such adaptation) but offered little or harmful benefit in SRI, possibly interacting poorly with its finer-grained acoustic models.
- Re-synthesis artifacts: Subtracting a long-term average can introduce echo/pre-echo or reverberation-like effects, especially noticeable in low-energy regions. These artifacts may confuse the more detailed SRI models.

A side observation was that PZM signals sounded “louder” after mean subtraction. The team noted that uniform gain alone shouldn’t change performance if applied consistently to train/test, unless absolute energy features are involved; perceived loudness might instead reflect altered SNR or band-dependent amplification when the mean estimate is imperfect (subtracting mean log-spectrum approximates division).

Mitigations discussed:
- VAD/high-pass-like treatment to zero or suppress very low-energy sections to remove echoes/pre-echoes.
- DC offset checks/compensation.
- Training on larger datasets to increase robustness.

Relatedly, earlier “mean phase subtraction” was deemed mathematically suspect; a revised approach subtracts the phase of the mean complex FFT instead. Further comparisons between SRI and HTK on matched data were encouraged.

- Mixed signals: For preparing IBM transcription, the group will start from Thilo’s automatic per‑channel segmentation and generate “beeped” mixed-audio (staggered mixed file) so transcribers can quickly tighten boundaries while listening to the mixed signal, then jump to individual channels only when overlaps or uncertainties appear. They’ll sample-check the beep files and send whole meetings where possible. Forced alignment to separate cross-talk on lapel channels proved unreliable; clean per-channel boundaries plus mixed-audio review is the near‑term path.

- VAD improvements: The new VAD uses noise‑compensated MFCCs with LDA and a small NN (9‑frame context, ~11k params). Current end‑to‑end VAD latency is ~220–270 ms (≈40 ms cleaning, delta/LDA, ~100 ms smoothing). To get under ~200 ms they’ll: move delta before online normalization, shorten windows, and shave ~20+ ms elsewhere. A parallel, low‑latency energy‑ratio VAD (post/noise-pre clean) is being explored (also multiband variants), though robust thresholding across corpora is hard. They may feed the VAD flag to the tandem net or multiply posteriors by an independent silence probability.

- VAD results: The updated system yields about 57.0% error‑rate reduction; a “cheating” clean‑speech VAD tops out near 62%. With the tandem stream, well‑matched and medium‑mismatch sets improve (~5% rel), but highly mismatched can degrade (~10–15% rel); overall weighted performance still improves.

- Headphones (postdoc A): New headphones were purchased to address low gain with the originals; transcribers prefer the new set and expect fewer corrections. More units may be ordered.

- Increasing space: They’re archiving regeneratable Broadcast News P‑files to tape, relocating static corpora (Aurora/Spanish/SPINE) off the Meeting Recorder disk, and freeing space for ~5–6 more meetings; additional disks are on order.

- Deadline: The evaluation is scheduled for November 15 (with internal emphasis on meeting any late latency requirements well before then).

- Special schools and the “new purpose”: Special schools remain central to the repurposed offer during COVID-19. They should, where possible, continue to support two priority groups: vulnerable learners (including many already self‑isolating due to health needs) and children of key workers. The presumption is to provide for these pupils in their usual special‑school setting rather than re‑sit­ing them elsewhere, both to protect continuity and because social‑distancing and specialist provision are harder to replicate in other venues. Even if only a minority can attend, those vulnerable pupils “deserve and need that support.” Headteachers and staff are expected to plan and deliver age‑appropriate activities and welfare check‑ins, with local authorities coordinating and supplementing staffing (e.g., youth workers, support staff). RCT was cited as already exemplifying proactive contact and arrangements for their special‑school cohorts.

- PDG for looked‑after children: role of schools vs regional consortia
  • Regional consortia now hold and strategically deploy the PDG‑LAC via regional LAC coordinators. This shift from per‑pupil in‑school allocations was made because looked‑after children often move placements; previously, funding stayed with the school even when the child moved.
  • Consortia can: (a) allocate resource directly to a school for an individual child, and/or (b) fund regional capacity‑building and universal approaches that disproportionately benefit LAC (e.g., attachment‑aware training, nurture provision, ACE‑informed practice). Some regions (e.g., EAS, ERW) frame this within wider “vulnerable learners” strategies.
  • Schools’ role is to implement the funded interventions, evidence impact, and be challenged/supported by consortia advisers on targeting and effectiveness.
  • Welsh Government has tightened scrutiny (clear expectations issued; in‑year reviews) and commissioned an independent evaluation (ICF) of PDG‑LAC use and impact.

In short: special schools stay open (as feasible) to deliver the new purpose locally, while for PDG‑LAC, consortia plan and allocate strategically and schools deliver and evidence impact.

User Interface, the Industrial Designer, and the Project Manager introduced a hand‑fitting, one‑handed prototype focused on simplicity and ergonomics. The Industrial Designer showed a form that molds to the palm, with the largest key as Power for easy discovery, channel up/down under the right thumb, and volume on the left (variously explored as buttons, a slider, or scroll). The IR emitter area was highlighted so it works whether pointed straight or held casually. A soft, spongy rubber outer “cover” stretches over a hard plastic core; buttons protrude through holes in the cover. They proposed lightweight plastics with rubberized, interchangeable covers (iPod‑style), company logo “R_R_” visible, and fruit/vegetable color themes (banana, watermelon, vanilla, etc.). The PM questioned how users would set it down; they agreed to widen/flatten the base so it can stand vertically and add another logo on the base. A Play‑Doh mockup conveyed the soft anti‑RSI feel, and an LED placement was noted.

On making it universal, they agreed the goal was a universal remote but discussed implications:
- Processor/coding: a universal unit must emit different IR “codes” per brand (“Morse code”), increasing processor complexity and influencing chip choice (simple vs regular/advanced; LCD or scroll wheels would push to higher chips).
- Feature scope: keep basic, widely supported functions (power, channel, volume, mute, menu) prominent; advanced brand‑specific settings should be secondary or omitted.
- Menu and multi‑digit entry: debated “plus” entry (1+2=12) vs tens/twenties keys and timeouts; noted legacy TVs differ, so they’d research standards to ensure double‑digit and menu access work across brands.
- Lost‑remote locator: placing the trigger on the TV breaks universality; they proposed a small external puck/sticker to ping the remote (beep/flash), TV‑brand‑agnostic.
- Language/labels: interchangeable covers could localize button text without changing electronics.

Voice control and LCD were considered but deprioritized as immature/too costly for a universal, simple design.

- Appearance: He proposed a bright, eye‑catching look: a blue body with yellow and multi‑colored buttons, and a fluorescent‑green LED/menu button. He emphasized a rounded, biomorphic “single‑curve” form that feels good in the hand, raised buttons, and an on/off key in a prominent, easy‑to‑find position. He liked color‑coding functional groups (e.g., orange for volume, distinct colors for channel controls). Initially he favored a soft, spongy rubber feel for “comfort,” but later accepted moving to a hard plastic case to meet cost targets, suggesting special-shaped/colored buttons (fruit motifs like cherry/lemon) to maintain visual appeal.

- Structure: He specified a strong plastic case and soft rubber buttons for better tactility, noting users touch buttons most. He stressed one‑handed ergonomics—thumb reach to all keys for small and large hands. He supported a simple push‑button interface (cheaper and more reliable than scroll systems), with clear symbols for an international market, and considered a secondary/slide‑away panel for advanced functions. To stay within budget while keeping innovations (e.g., voice recognition, kinetic/battery options), he recommended switching the casing to plastic and limiting special materials, while retaining distinct forms for key buttons.

- Customer preferences: He cited research and observations that buyers prioritize “fancy” look and feel, small size, and ease of use over complex functions. Younger users might value quick channel swapping and playful designs; many customers would pay for a good-looking remote and prefer soft/spongy textures if durability is maintained. He suggested large, clearly labeled or symbolic buttons, and even customizable/changeable covers to appeal to trendy users and children. In evaluation, he rated the prototype high on fanciness (~2/7) and kept ease-of-use a priority, acknowledging minor fashion trade-offs when shifting to plastic to hit cost.
