Thilo’s automatic segmenter is up and running well and is now central to the workflow. The team reports high recall from the segmenter; even with some over-segmentation (lower precision), that behavior is acceptable and potentially beneficial because it allows training/adaptation of background/noise models and handling of microphone transients during recognition. Based on this performance, they plan to move meeting recognition experiments from hand segmentations to Thilo’s automatic segmentations.

Integration with transcription has also advanced. Pre-segmentations from Thilo are described as “extremely helpful” by transcribers. After problems with “too many beeps” in a prior run, the cueing scheme around segments was changed: instead of a single beep at the end, segments now begin with beep + spoken digit ID + beep. A new sample meeting has been processed with Thilo’s segmentation and sent to the transcribers to verify that this revision fixes the earlier beep problem and to gauge turnaround.

For evaluation and improvement, they plan to derive speech/non-speech labels from completed transcripts to compare manual adjustments with the automatic boundaries. Note that a few recent meetings began without pre-segmentation while Thilo was briefly away, then were merged with automatic segments later, which complicates direct diffs but the original automatic outputs are retained for analysis.

No core algorithmic changes to the segmenter itself were reported; recent changes are primarily in pipeline integration and labeling/cueing around its outputs, with forthcoming work to exploit its posterior information and to adapt noise models for recognition using these automatic segments.

- Price disagreement in the interactive evaluation: The Industrial Designer rated price as “very cheap” because the concept relied on simple, old, robust components (push‑buttons, no exotic mechanics), which fit the “keep it simple” reading of user needs and avoided costly innovation. The User Interface designer pushed the score higher (more expensive) because meeting the user requirement of “few buttons, menu-driven control” and the hot trends (stylish/fruit-themed, possibly spongy casing) implied real software/menu development and interface programming effort—costs not visible in the hardware bill of materials. In short: ID saw low BOM; UI counted UI/firmware development and finish options.

- Disagreement on redesign after product evaluation: UI objected to the plan of launching with no redesign window after user testing, arguing that without iteration the product could flop on overlooked usability issues. The PM’s stance was “no more changes to the basic design” until a second generation; UI insisted that user feedback must inform tweaks before launch.

- Why yellow and red as basic colors: UI advocated company colors for brand recognition (earlier favoring bright yellow) and, in the cost exercise, limiting to standardized base colors (yellow/red) reduced “special color” charges while still aligning with the fruit/visibility trend. This balanced branding, trend fit, and the tight 12.5€ unit cost target.

- Marketing’s disagreement with UI on shape: Marketing challenged UI’s preferred shapes (abstract “blob,” single-curved body, later the ball/pineapple) on practical and market grounds—top‑heavy balance, two‑hand use, and jump navigation concerns—while favoring a clearer fruit silhouette (e.g., banana) that was on‑trend, easy to spot (less likely to be lost), and more retail‑distinctive.

- Dafydd Evans: He views the Welsh bac’s original employability aim as sound but says it currently prepares learners for work only inconsistently. Employers don’t understand it—he even questions the “Welsh bac” label and prefers “Skills Challenge Certificate.” He argues the qualification has “lost its way,” trying to be both a rigorous academic credential and a vehicle for soft/employability skills. It works best when vocational staff contextualise it within courses, but overall impact is weakened by poor employer buy‑in, variable delivery, and competing priorities (e.g., GCSE resits at Levels 1–2). He calls for a review led by employers to refocus on employability and entrepreneurship and to structure industry engagement more effectively.

- Kay Martin: She sees mixed effectiveness. Employers primarily want the main professional qualification plus literacy, numeracy, and digital skills. While the Welsh bac can help some A‑level learners (especially for university progression), it does not necessarily make many vocational learners—e.g., in health and social care—more employable. In her college, other initiatives (Career Ready mentoring/internships, WorldSkills) develop work‑readiness more directly and engage employers better. She highlights excessive paperwork and urges a refocus on experiential learning. Overall: useful for some, not the most effective or employer‑engaging route for many.

- Nick Brazil: From regular employer board feedback, he finds the Welsh bac rarely demanded by industry. Employers back the original vision, but the qualification has become bureaucratic and outcomes‑driven, crowding out genuine skills development and overloading learners alongside core qualifications. He questions whether it currently delivers the employability skills employers need and suggests revisiting its design—or developing those skills through alternative, non‑qualification routes—so it better serves learners’ progression into work.

The team aligned on a TV‑only remote with a stripped‑down, intuitive feature set, then explored enhancements and the underlying working design. Core functions: power on/off (preferably a large, easy‑reach button), channel up/down, volume up/down, mute, and a numeric keypad (0–9, plus “enter”). Less‑used functions (audio/video settings, subtitles) would be accessed via a single Menu button or hidden under a flap/drawer to keep the surface uncluttered.

Additional ideas:
- Channel navigation via a scroll wheel integrated with a favorites “zapping” mode; the wheel is scroll‑only (not a press button). They noted a drop could spin the wheel; a possible “trigger + scroll” combination may mitigate accidental changes.
- A cradle/base station with two charging contacts and a “find my remote” locator button; the remote would beep when lost. They debated rechargeable vs standard batteries and leaned to batteries to limit cost/complexity unless power needs grow (e.g., with voice).
- Ruggedized, ergonomic body: white plastic chassis with rubberized red grip and rubber buttons for durability. Marketing prefers silver/black finishes to match TVs; corporate color/slogan to be integrated subtly (logo, accent LED).

Working design and components:
- Standard IR transmission for speed to market; clear line‑of‑sight considerations if voice/mic were added.
- Component stack: user input (buttons/scroll, optional mic), logic/smart chip, IR transmitter/receiver path, power source, and a visible activity LED for user feedback.
- Costing/positioning: estimated build €15.4–€15.8; target retail €35–€50 for a mid to upper segment; lifetime normal‑use guarantee was suggested.
- Voice recognition considered as optional/upgrade path (on/off selectable), valued for accessibility but flagged for cost, reliability, and maturity.

They also proposed grouping controls into “device,” “audio,” and “other” to guide layout and usability.

- Market range and price: The PM repeatedly set the frame as an international consumer market (Europe, North America; also Australia/US mentioned). Target retail price is €25 with a maximum production cost of €12.50. He stressed this rules out “ultra‑high‑tech” additions and pushes use of off‑the‑shelf parts (e.g., standard IR, lithium‑ion, rubber/plastic casing).

- Target groups: He wanted broad accessibility (“grannies to kids”), but pragmatically framed the core buyers as style‑conscious consumers under roughly 60 with some disposable income—i.e., people replacing a remote, not business users.

- On Marketing’s proposed features: He welcomed differentiation only if it truly adds value and remains user‑friendly. Positive signals: a “find‑my‑remote” locator (even a fun default sound), a bright, brand‑forward color (e.g., yellow) and rubberized, ergonomic styling. Cautions: fruit/veg theming is secondary to usability and brand; articulation/spongy skins need a firm internal frame; an LCD/menu is acceptable if it replaces clutter (numeric keypad) but requires a pricier chip; USB/PC setup is nice‑to‑have but may be cost‑prohibitive.

- Multipurpose feasibility: He acknowledged a single remote for TV/DVD/VCR/cable is attractive and feasible via IR code libraries, with optional PC programming. However, he also pressed to prioritize core TV tasks (channel/volume) so multi‑device capability must not bloat cost or complexity.

- Cost constraints and financial targets: €25 retail, €12.50 COGS, profit target €50M. He calculated ~4 million units needed and emphasized bulk procurement and standard components to hit margins.

- Selling target necessity: He explicitly asked Marketing to quantify units required to meet the €50M goal to size the market and focus efforts.

- Target market and next‑step plan (style discussion): Aim at broad consumers (esp. under ~60), stylish but simple. Keep brand elements (logo/slogan). Proceed to detailed design with UI and ID collaborating; maintain minimal physical layout, refine LCD/menu, and plan user evaluation later.

User Interface consistently framed decisions around the stated cost and profit goals while protecting the visible value of the product. On constraints, they acknowledged the head‑office targets of a €25 retail price and ~€12.50 production cost, and the profit ambition (cited as ~€50M), noting the implied sales volume—“we have to sell at least four million”—to make the business case work. They did briefly float the idea of raising the allowed cost/price (“make it costly”), but ultimately accepted that the team had to work to the given specification and could only recommend a higher‑priced variant for later.

Regarding trade‑offs, UI was clear that customer‑perceived benefits (shape, colors, customizable fronts, lighting) should not be sacrificed to hit cost: “shape and colours, that’s something we shouldn’t compromise.” By contrast, they viewed the power source as low salience for buyers. On the kinetic battery specifically, UI said “I think we could change the battery,” and emphasized “customers never said anything about the battery,” signaling comfort with replacing the kinetic solution with standard cells if it helped meet budget.

In summary: UI accepted the tight cost/price targets and volume/profit aims, prioritized maintaining the distinctive look-and-feel (what customers notice), and was pragmatic about swapping out the kinetic battery for conventional batteries to control costs—seeing that change as low risk to user appeal while preserving the features that drive purchase. They also recognized that premium features could be proposed for a higher-tier version rather than burden the base model’s cost.

They disagreed because they were optimizing for different priorities under tight constraints.

- Target user and usability: The team aimed at seniors (60–80). The Industrial Designer argued kinetic energy conflicts with this user: “you basically shake your remote… I don't think that older people like to shake their remote before they use it.” Marketing favored a docking station instead, positioning it as a marketable convenience that also houses the “find my remote” feature. Thus, ID prioritized ease-of-use and minimal user effort; Marketing prioritized a compelling story and accessory-led value.

- Simplicity vs feature creep: Marketing floated making the unit upgradable (e.g., via a card) to extend life and create a premium narrative (lifetime guarantee, exclusivity). The Industrial Designer pushed back, noting the current hardware/interface wouldn’t support future functions without “more buttons” and likely a different version. Upgradability threatened the product’s deliberately simple, robust UI and could introduce confusion—echoing concerns that added flexibility might “make it less usable.”

- Cost and manufacturability: The product had to be built for roughly €12.50–€15.80. Kinetic systems and modular upgradability risked higher BOM, engineering complexity, and warranty exposure. Marketing acknowledged warranty implications; ID focused on feasibility and keeping to the minimalist, durable design and low cost.

In short, Marketing sought differentiators (docking station as a hero feature, upgradability for future value and positioning), while the Industrial Designer defended ergonomic simplicity, reliability, and cost control for the senior audience—leading to divergence on kinetic energy and upgradability.

- HEFCW’s current powers: The 2015 Act gave HEFCW a clear set of intervention and sanction powers with the ability to escalate where necessary. HEFCW told the committee these can feel inflexible and “threatening,” and cumbersome for swift action. The Minister disagreed they are frightening or unusable, but accepted the gap between informal “soft” influence and the strongest sanctions is too wide.

- Intended changes: In the forthcoming PCET legislation, the Minister plans to equip the new Tertiary Education Commission with a more graduated toolkit. This would add flexible, preventative powers (e.g., advice and guidance, enhanced monitoring) before moving to formal, punitive steps, and ensure the regulator is structured and resourced to keep close, day‑to‑day relationships across a larger provider base. The Government is also exploring a regulatory condition on good governance.

- Use in practice: HEFCW generally relies on informal measures given the small size of the sector and strong relationships. Even in recent high‑profile cases (Swansea; Trinity St David), HEFCW has not deployed formal intervention powers, instead supporting institutions. The Minister expects HEFCW to use its full remit if needed, but trusts its professional judgment.

- Current situation and FE/HE closures: Universities and colleges are autonomous. They have moved rapidly to suspend in‑person teaching and deliver online, with limited on‑site provision for the most vulnerable learners. The Government is in regular dialogue with Universities Wales/UUK, colleges and independent training providers. Emergency coronavirus legislation will give Welsh Ministers temporary powers to close “schools or other educational institutions,” or issue “continuity directions” (including directing provision to remain open and redeploying staff) if required. At the time of discussion, decisions on FE and HE closures remained with institutions.

The team will position the product as a fashionable, high‑quality universal remote priced at €25 with a target unit cost of €12.50 to preserve a strong per‑unit margin. Marketing will make it globally acceptable by using internationally recognizable icons, culturally neutral colors (standard black/silver to match TVs/DVDs), and simple, familiar layouts (kept number pad, clearly sized buttons, a prominent mode‑switch button for TV/DVD, and minimal clutter). They will study competitor remotes, adopt what works, and differentiate on sleek, trend‑forward design and better materials/feel while ensuring it’s still immediately recognizable as a remote and easy to learn.

To drive adoption and volume, the remote will be universally compatible (NTSC/PAL, multiple brands) and specifically integrated with the company’s own TVs and new DVD player, so one remote controls both—supporting cross‑selling and potential bundling. They will add user‑valued, low‑cost features such as a “locator/page” function to find the remote, and consider light customization (colored indicators, dual‑function labeling) without sacrificing simplicity for non‑tech users.

To lift revenue beyond the base unit, the team will launch interchangeable “fronts/faceplates” distributed worldwide: a standard, mass‑appeal front and optional trendy skins (e.g., colors for kids’ rooms), creating an accessory stream and helping the product feel fresh. Marketing’s messaging will emphasize style (Apple‑like sleekness), quality, and universal convenience, while ensuring consistency with the company’s product line.

Together, margin control (€12.50 COGS), global appeal and compatibility for high volume, ecosystem integration, and accessories upsell (faceplates) form the path to the €50M profit target.

- Policies and measures: The Healthy Weight: Healthy Wales draft strategy takes an all‑age, whole‑system approach with strong focus on children. Officials are open to targets but wary of unrealistic ones; robust evaluation metrics are planned. Indicative investment discussed was £8–10m per year, alongside reprioritising existing spend; Welsh sugar levy consequentials (~£56m over two years) are noted, but Ministers prefer not to hypothecate. Governance will combine national oversight with local leadership via public services boards. Potential measures include legislation to restrict price promotions and energy drinks, tighter planning controls on hot food takeaways near schools (evidence‑led), and updating the 2013 Healthy Eating in Schools regulations to align with current SACN sugar guidance. Expansion of the Child Measurement Programme to a second measurement point is under consultation. A review of the clinical obesity pathway for children is under way, with stronger support for severely obese children. Early‑life actions (breastfeeding, Healthy Start) and tackling inequalities and food affordability are priorities.

- Physical education: Increasing children’s activity is central for health and wellbeing. Sport Wales, Public Health Wales and Natural Resources Wales are coordinating school‑based programmes. Emphasis is on enjoyable, inclusive activity (addressing teenage drop‑off, especially among girls). Possible statutory PE guidance will be tested via consultation. Better school design and community access (changing rooms, facilities) should be guided by health impact assessments. Teacher training/CPD and school‑level leadership are key; accountability should sit above individual teachers.

- Food provision for free‑school‑meal children during the pandemic: With schools repurposed as hubs, immediate priorities are childcare for key workers, safeguarding vulnerable learners, and continuing FSM. Local authorities and schools are implementing emergency arrangements from the first closure week, moving to resilient hub models, with the aim of seamless FSM provision through the normal Easter holiday. Emergency legislation may allow temporary flexibilities (e.g., food standards) to maintain provision.

- Why the curved/ergonomic design:
User Interface advocated a biomorphic, curved form so the remote would conform to the hand, improve comfort, and place controls naturally. They stressed that the most critical curve was on the underside so the joystick could rest over the edge of the hand, with a rubberized grip through the middle for a “spongy,” comfortable feel. They also considered articulating the LCD for left- and right-handed use and possibly an ovoid joystick base to suit handedness. The double/single-curved casing and rubber keypad area were meant to enhance ergonomics and visual distinctiveness.

- Reasons for agreement on key features:
• Easy to use: They converged on minimal controls (two buttons + joystick) and moving navigation to an LCD-driven menu, reducing clutter and making common actions simpler, with the joystick placed in an ergonomic thumb position. They acknowledged technophobes might find the look unfamiliar but still treated the simplified interface as usability-positive. 
• Fashion: Real Reactions’ strategy was to “put the fashion in electronics” via fruit/veg inspiration. The team leaned into a banana-themed, curved, yellow design (with discussion of lighting/transparent material), aligning with current fashion cues; this was ultimately rated very high.
• Easy to find: Because the electronic locator was cut for cost, they agreed to use a bright, non-dingy color (notably yellow) so the remote stands out “in a big pile of” living-room clutter.
• Robust: A rubber, “spongy” outer shell around a plastic substructure was seen as impact-absorbing and protective; they rated robustness very high.

- How UI evaluated fashion:
UI initially questioned how “fruit and veggie” the form truly was, but in the final scoring accepted and endorsed a top fashion rating, citing the banana-inspired curvature, yellow color, and alignment with the company’s fashion brief.
